componenttext: (Operator Instructions) We'll get our first question from Jeff Stein with Soleil Securities.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about the dollars committed to seasonal inventory programs for the back half of the year, given perhaps we might be facing a more tepid consumer spending environment?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about the dollars committed to seasonal inventory programs for the back half of the year, given perhaps we might be facing a more tepid consumer spending environment?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have a decent program planned in seasonal for the fall, and it's a planned up in the range of where our guidance is or slightly higher. Frankly, there is a lot of change and newness in seasonal this year, particularly in the lighting classification whe
componenttext:
We have a decent program planned in seasonal for the fall, and it's a planned up in the range of where our guidance is or slightly higher. Frankly, there is a lot of change and newness in seasonal this year, particularly in the lighting classification where a large percentage of the light class is new lighting, LED lighting, and the biggest most impressive increase is that we've experienced in the tree class vacation last couple of years. There is new looks and new styles at really great value.
So we're pretty excited about the potential in Christmas, particularly in the seasonal business. And holiday harvest, which is an early part of the business, has started of very strong too, which was not great last year for us. So I feel pretty good about that. We have a fair investment. We have enough to do the plan that we've got right now and exceed it slightly if we have to. So that's the place where I feel particularly good about our business for the fourth quarter.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Joe, if you could talk a little bit about the leverage point for the business. I think at the beginning of the year, you were talking about the ability to leverage comp. Your SG&A had a zero comp. And I am wondering with increase in debit
componenttext: I was wondering, Joe, if you could talk a little bit about the leverage point for the business. I think at the beginning of the year, you were talking about the ability to leverage comp. Your SG&A had a zero comp. And I am wondering with increase in debit card fees and shipping costs if you still believe that's a realistic goal for the year?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as the year goes, we haven't changed that. Certainly there are some variances throughout the year. Year-to-date, we've reduced SG&A about 120 basis points. That's excluding depreciation. That's what's showing on the P&L. But the third quarter has
componenttext:
I think as the year goes, we haven't changed that. Certainly there are some variances throughout the year. Year-to-date, we've reduced SG&A about 120 basis points. That's excluding depreciation. That's what's showing on the P&L. But the third quarter has some unique items, and that's what we talked about in our prepared comments.
We do believe we'll revert back to a strong leverage in the fourth quarter. But the third quarter, we still have the higher debit card fees. We've got the equity-related costs that we've talked about throughout the year. But the incremental store opening costs are going to account for about 20 basis points. But we certainly want to get those stores opened. They are key to our holiday sales growth.
And D&TS, distribution and transportation, the third quarter we're starting to anniversary the closing of our California, D.C., last year in the third quarter and also the dedicated fleet contracts were negotiated in the third quarter of last year. So we're starting to anniversary those benefits.
And the volatile market for trucking costs and the prospect of peak season surcharges, we just think it's prudent not to expect leverage and distribution transportation. And in advertising, the shift-out of one ad circular, each ad circular costs about $2 million, shifting one from second to third quarter. We think it's prudent not to forecast leverage in advertising in the third quarter. But again, that (inaudible) third quarter. We think we'll leverage advertising about 20 basis points for the year.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take the next question from David Mann with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: We'll take the next question from David Mann with Johnson Rice.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you said for the second half you're slightly more positive on your outlook, can you just clarify after the second quarter, where sales a little lighter though you did do a little better on margin. Why you feel a little more positive about the seco
componenttext: I think you said for the second half you're slightly more positive on your outlook, can you just clarify after the second quarter, where sales a little lighter though you did do a little better on margin. Why you feel a little more positive about the second half.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sales weren't what I considered to be lighter in the second quarter. You could interpret it that way, but in our market segment we've performed at the upper end at 3.8 comp. And our guidance for the third and the fourth quarter in the back half of the yea
componenttext: Sales weren't what I considered to be lighter in the second quarter. You could interpret it that way, but in our market segment we've performed at the upper end at 3.8 comp. And our guidance for the third and the fourth quarter in the back half of the year is two to four. So that's pretty consistent with the performance of what we're seeing right now.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of your costs outlook on product, can you just talk a little bit about initial market, what you're seeing right now in terms of how that might look in the back half and then also any preliminary thoughts about some of the import cost inc
componenttext: And then in terms of your costs outlook on product, can you just talk a little bit about initial market, what you're seeing right now in terms of how that might look in the back half and then also any preliminary thoughts about some of the import cost increases that you might see next year as we're hearing from a lot of folks about inflation out of China.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I'm not sure exactly what's going to happen next year. We're finding that out just about right now. We've seen about initial costs for Lawn & Garden for the spring. And I think we've done a relatively good job maintaining costs. Commodity prices ha
componenttext:
David, I'm not sure exactly what's going to happen next year. We're finding that out just about right now. We've seen about initial costs for Lawn & Garden for the spring. And I think we've done a relatively good job maintaining costs. Commodity prices have been challenging when it comes overseas and domestically when it comes to steel and when it comes to cotton prices. So those things have been slightly challenged.
The other issue from the orient has been a challenge fro a wage rate standpoint. People are getting paid more and of course the fact that a number of factories over the last 18 months have closed overseas. So the strong have survived but there is a cost of doing a business with the strong that are surviving over there. But preplanning that business gives us a unique opportunity to know what kind of value we need to be retailing merchandise. And what we continue to do and we've done year-over-year-over-year and will continue to do going forward is put more value in merchandise if prices have to go up for one reason or another.
So we're doing the best job we possibly can along with every other retailer I think, and around the world. And fighting the fight and fighting the battles. As long as we continue to offer great value as compared to everybody else in the market place, we think we're doing a really good job and we continue to do that.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, at the beginning of the year in discussing the key locations strategy as I recall you're suggesting there is sales per square foot that exceed the traditional store by approximately $30 I believe during the first year. Can you update us on how thes
componenttext: Steve, at the beginning of the year in discussing the key locations strategy as I recall you're suggesting there is sales per square foot that exceed the traditional store by approximately $30 I believe during the first year. Can you update us on how these stores are in fact opening compared to the ramp of the interest and the locations?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't, and I am going to let Chuck do it since he is the Real Estate maven and he's sitting right here.
componenttext: I can't, and I am going to let Chuck do it since he is the Real Estate maven and he's sitting right here.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we still are seeing those consistent performances in those locations, Dave. They continue to meet if not exceed our expectations. And that's one of the reasons that we're focused so heavily on those sites.
componenttext: I think we still are seeing those consistent performances in those locations, Dave. They continue to meet if not exceed our expectations. And that's one of the reasons that we're focused so heavily on those sites.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: So those stores, I think we were talking about doing $180 to $190 a square foot. And remember, we've only opened seven so far this year, Dan. But there's quite a few opening in the third and the fourth quarter. And we're real pleased with the performance
componenttext:
So those stores, I think we were talking about doing $180 to $190 a square foot. And remember, we've only opened seven so far this year, Dan. But there's quite a few opening in the third and the fourth quarter. And we're real pleased with the performance early on in each one of those stores, but I'm always very, very cautious about talking about getting too excited one way or another about something that's very new and fresh. Let's let them get through the Christmas season. But there hasn't been, that I can remember, any disappointments in any of the stores we've opened so far in any locations this year.
We continue to be real excited about that. We'd love to have more and more opportunities for those better retail sites.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then as a follow up question, consumables were weaker, it looks like during the second quarter, which is counter to what a lot of other retailers are telling us. I know you've had a lot of dollars and a lot of time into improving the organization, the cle
componenttext: Then as a follow up question, consumables were weaker, it looks like during the second quarter, which is counter to what a lot of other retailers are telling us. I know you've had a lot of dollars and a lot of time into improving the organization, the cleanliness of that department, could you give us your view on why consumables is not performing a little better.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, firs and foremost, consumables has been the strongest business we've had over the last five years. If not performing at the level the rest of the business is performing at right now. But that's partially because I believe finally for the first time
componenttext:
Well, firs and foremost, consumables has been the strongest business we've had over the last five years. If not performing at the level the rest of the business is performing at right now. But that's partially because I believe finally for the first time in about two or three years, the discretionary parts of our business, which is 70% of our total, is finally seeing a resurgence, particularly in the home, furniture and seasonal parts of the business.
It's not overall consumables that are not performing quite as well. It is certain segments of the business really, the health and beauty aids part and the organization parts, plastic and things like that, paper, continue to see really good deals and continue to perform very, very well. I think we're a little bit more challenged right this second. And frankly, I have heard that other retailers are not as happy about their parts of the businesses really and the food part of the business.
We're pretty active on what's going on there, although a want a flat business to be up 3% and a 3% business to be up 5%, 6% or 7%. We're very vigilant about really making sure that our offerings are as great and extreme value as other parts of our business. And we've got some real exciting ideas for 2011 that we'll share as we get closer to 2011 in the food parts of our business.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll next hear from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: We'll next hear from Meredith Adler with Barclays Capital.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to talk a little bit about the cost structure. I understand in the third quarter the timing of anniversarying some of the transportation and logistics reductions. I understand that. But that seems to me that that's a permanent reduction year-over
componenttext:
I'd like to talk a little bit about the cost structure. I understand in the third quarter the timing of anniversarying some of the transportation and logistics reductions. I understand that. But that seems to me that that's a permanent reduction year-over-year. Not reduction, that's not the right word. But you won't see the same improvement.
What are you doing? Is there anything in particular that you think will kind of match that, or is it now going to be a function of generating sales to leverage fixed costs?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did say early on this year that distribution and transportation dollars would increase year-over-year, just not at same rate of sales. So we do need some level of comp to continue to leverage that part of the business. That's been our guidance for the
componenttext:
We did say early on this year that distribution and transportation dollars would increase year-over-year, just not at same rate of sales. So we do need some level of comp to continue to leverage that part of the business. That's been our guidance for the last couple of quarters.
I guess what's unique about third quarter is we had these two large initiatives last year that generated significant leverage for the past 12 months. We're starting to anniversary those at a time when quite frankly the outbound and inbound parts of our business are at their peak, as we're looking to holiday season. We're receiving or shipping a lot of goods on the lowest sales base throughout the year. So it's the more challenging quarter. It always has been from the leverage standpoint in D&TS.
We're forecasting that leverage to return, albeit not at the same rate in fourth quarter. So from a productivity standpoint, all distribution centers are challenged, the merchants continue to be challenged on how they are delivering goods and the carton value or the case pack value there to try to make our buildings more efficient.
We have certain another smaller initiatives in place going into next year to try to save on costs. But I guess going forward, we've looking at continuing to try to leverage that part of the business albeit at not the same rate where we've been for the last two or three years. I mean we did what I think most people would do when they have looked at the cost structure at business. We took the biggest ideas first and executed them, and executed them very well. Now we need a little improvement on the sales line and some of the initiatives will be of smaller dollar amounts.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And outside of distribution logistics, I think you've worked very hard on energy management. Is that likely to be significant? Is there anything else that's really significant?
componenttext: And outside of distribution logistics, I think you've worked very hard on energy management. Is that likely to be significant? Is there anything else that's really significant?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, to set out the year, we talked about three key areas where dollars would go down. Forgetting about sales for a minute, real dollars reducing year-over-year in advertising, utilities as you just mentioned and also health benefits, as we redesigned ou
componenttext:
Well, to set out the year, we talked about three key areas where dollars would go down. Forgetting about sales for a minute, real dollars reducing year-over-year in advertising, utilities as you just mentioned and also health benefits, as we redesigned our health plan. And also completed some audit work there on eligible associates. So those three areas we've committed to real dollars being down this year.
Additionally, we continue to see opportunity to leverage store payroll and also distribution transportation cost on an annual basis. So we know those dollars are going to increase, because as Steve has said a number of times we are going to pay for performance, we are going to continue to grant merit increases et cetera. So we know there's going to be some cost increase there.
We just don't see it at the same rate of sales. So we do see leverage and opportunities there going forward. I think it's important to understand even the leverage that we gave today for the year and for the third and fourth quarter those scenarios, we are incurring some pretty hefty increases in expanses, particularly on debit cards, and also in equity related expanses, which as you know we file on our cues so you can see those numbers.
From our view any way, the business performs pretty well as continuing to perform pretty well from an expense standpoint. Here in 2010, now some four plus years later, since we've started some of these initiatives.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on inventory, thank you for the explanation, fully understand what's going on. I guess the question is really, how should we think about inventory by the end of the year. I mean, should we expect it to work through a little up relative to last ye
componenttext: Question on inventory, thank you for the explanation, fully understand what's going on. I guess the question is really, how should we think about inventory by the end of the year. I mean, should we expect it to work through a little up relative to last year, flattish with last year, if you could give us any color on that?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're also comfortable saying, we don't expect 10% at the end of every quarter. So that number ought to work it's way down over time. I would differ to Steve to talk about turn, but we've given guidance that says we will continue to expect to leve
componenttext: I think we're also comfortable saying, we don't expect 10% at the end of every quarter. So that number ought to work it's way down over time. I would differ to Steve to talk about turn, but we've given guidance that says we will continue to expect to leverage or improve the inventory turnover of this business. And even last year's number at 3.7 times, which was a record. We don't think we're near maxing that number. So again, for our comp expectations are 3.5 to 4.5 when we do the math. Obviously we have to have a little less inventory than that to continue to drive turnover.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, we expect improvement in turnover, I have always said that I'm not going to try to play to a metric at the end of a quarter just because the market maybe happy or not happy, we're in the business of opportunity. And that's what we have always planned
componenttext:
Joe, we expect improvement in turnover, I have always said that I'm not going to try to play to a metric at the end of a quarter just because the market maybe happy or not happy, we're in the business of opportunity. And that's what we have always planned our business by. There's going to be quarters where we're under inventories and there's going to be quarters where we're over inventories. I have to tell you, I feel very good about our inventory content right now, and I like what we have.
There is nothing that we really have in any big way that I wouldn't want to have at this particular time. We're very well positioned for the third and into the fourth quarter, right this second. The inventories will be back into line where they need to be. As long as there's no opportunities that we don't know about yet, which is our business going into the fourth quarter. But right now, we have control over our inventories. And we are where we want to be right now.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, are you seeing any changes in behavior by your customers. Obviously there is a little more discretionary and I know you're geared toward store 70% discretionary, but still. And maybe what they're buying or what they're putting in their basket? Are
componenttext: Steve, are you seeing any changes in behavior by your customers. Obviously there is a little more discretionary and I know you're geared toward store 70% discretionary, but still. And maybe what they're buying or what they're putting in their basket? Are they putting more higher end product in the basket or are you seeing more units?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely higher end average unit retail ticket and average unit retail is up. And it's at the high end of the spectrum and almost everyone of the classifications; I think I alluded to that in my comments. Where they were buying in the second quarter and
componenttext:
Absolutely higher end average unit retail ticket and average unit retail is up. And it's at the high end of the spectrum and almost everyone of the classifications; I think I alluded to that in my comments. Where they were buying in the second quarter and for instance they were buying at the high end, and where they were buying in seasonal, they were buying in a better quality sets in a better quality tools.
So they are not afraid, I'm not real clear in my mind, if that's a function of the fact that they are comfortable doing it or that we're actually attracting a different or an additional customer base that appreciates value that may have not understood us in the past. One of the things that we do is, Joe, as you well know, is we spend an awful lot of time understanding not only our customer, but the customer who shops us frequently and infrequently too.
And the place where we seen to have made the most headway in the last six months, and the last time we actually talked to a customer was a customer that was a more infrequent shopper that we are finally starting to attract. And that's been an initiative over the last six or seven months that we hope to appreciate more going into the third and fourth quarter.
We saw in the fourth quarter of last year, I think it's one of the reasons that comps were as good as they were, in the first quarter and in the second quarter we're attracting a customer that didn't shop us as frequently as before. Clearly our existing core customers are as loyal as they've ever been, and their spend is slightly higher than it's ever been before too. So I think both of those combinations have been very positive for us.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Patrick McKeever with MKM Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Patrick McKeever with MKM Partners.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the furniture, the higher inventories in furniture. I was just wondering if you could discuss just some broad comments even there on just the timing. I know as we move toward holiday, typically you don't like to necessarily do a furniture deal. And I k
componenttext: On the furniture, the higher inventories in furniture. I was just wondering if you could discuss just some broad comments even there on just the timing. I know as we move toward holiday, typically you don't like to necessarily do a furniture deal. And I know this is not the time of year that your customer typically shops for furniture. So just wondering about the timing there.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me address a couple of things. First off, what we have in furniture right now is very conscious; we intentionally wanted to do it. I understand your comment about it's not the time in year; you may interpret that. But people shop for furniture 12 mont
componenttext:
Let me address a couple of things. First off, what we have in furniture right now is very conscious; we intentionally wanted to do it. I understand your comment about it's not the time in year; you may interpret that. But people shop for furniture 12 months out of the year. The volume level in the third quarter is not as high as the second quarter or the first quarter.
But we learnt two things that happen for the third quarter, why we're so encouraged and like our position. We had something that we put together in the first quarter that we called the Roadshow, it was exceptional value in upholstery and in dining, and in RTA, and in a little bit of lighting and mattresses that just was outstanding and helped drive the double-digit comp in the first quarter and into the second quarter. And so, we put one together immediately for the third quarter and we're certainly encouraged about that performance. That's number one and that's a piece of the inventory there.
Number two is remember we're in the opportunistic business, and Stratolounger in Stratford, which I can say now is a name that we control beside the fact that we bought the closeout, gave us an opportunity to have name brand closeouts that resonate with the customer that we were never able to have before. And we're going to absolutely take advantage of that when we can.
And that wasn't preplanned for the quarter many months ago. It's one of those typical opportunities where we get a telephone call and the bank says they're looking to reduce inventory. Who wants the inventory the worse than who can take the inventory off of our hands?
And at the same time we were able to negotiate the names, which is something that we think can add great value going into 2011, and further forward, I think it's a name that is national and the consumer understands. So both of those investments are where the real additional inventory is in the third quarter in furniture, and we like our position where we're at an awful lot in both of those deals.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on advertising, how about television advertising as we move into the holidays? Do you have any significant changes planned there? I saw one of the recent TV commercials recently, a few days ago with the new focus there. How effective are you
componenttext: And then just on advertising, how about television advertising as we move into the holidays? Do you have any significant changes planned there? I saw one of the recent TV commercials recently, a few days ago with the new focus there. How effective are you finding the television campaign?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're finding the television campaign is really resonating, We're getting better recognition than some of the national competitors and the ratings that we're getting from media feedback, We think the Think Extreme Value campaign is the best campaign we've
componenttext:
We're finding the television campaign is really resonating, We're getting better recognition than some of the national competitors and the ratings that we're getting from media feedback, We think the Think Extreme Value campaign is the best campaign we've ever come up with, and for the first time we will drive that campaign into the Christmas season. And clearly, I am not going to talk about specifically until you see it starting in early November. But those television commercials are actually shot and in the books already, and we have a very aggressive media campaign.
The spend has shifted over the last couple of years from what is now 55%, 45% media. In fact probably we'll shift up maybe a tick going into the fourth quarter. But we'll be aggressive and we'll be on television, and you'll see that campaign with a Christmas flavor to it starting in November.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Laura Champine with Cowen and Company.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Rob stepping in for Laura. I was wondering if you guys could touch on or maybe highlight one or two things that really gives you confidence regarding your Q4 same store sales guidance. It just seems like some retailers have been a little reluctant to
componenttext: It's Rob stepping in for Laura. I was wondering if you guys could touch on or maybe highlight one or two things that really gives you confidence regarding your Q4 same store sales guidance. It just seems like some retailers have been a little reluctant to talk about Q4, and you guys are projecting a guidance of 2% to 4% comp increase. I was wondering if you could just touch on that a little bit.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I am clearly not going to share the all-important strategies, but I'll tell you what gives us the most confidence. You know us pretty well and I think a number of you out there know us pretty well. We do probably some of the most definitive testing to und
componenttext:
I am clearly not going to share the all-important strategies, but I'll tell you what gives us the most confidence. You know us pretty well and I think a number of you out there know us pretty well. We do probably some of the most definitive testing to understand our business year-over-year of any retailer that I know out there. We ran about 30 to 35 'how high is high tests' last Christmas season on a number of items' classifications and product concepts that gave us tremendous confidence to step out to the fourth quarter of this year.
We don't consider it an overly aggressive campaign other than the fact that you are seeing a lot of people who comp'ed up may be in our range of 5% plus last Christmas. But our business isn't about, well, we're up 5% and we're worried about this year; our business is all about how much higher can we take our business.
We still think we're underdeveloped on a sales per square foot and on sales per average store basis, and we have a lot of upside. And we learned a tremendous amount last Christmas. Even on that 5% plus comp that there is huge upside opportunity, when we offer extreme value and the right merchandize. And we are absolutely laser-focused on those opportunities for this year, and we are committed to and planned with some real good history telling us that we can perform at that level.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rob also keep in mind the other two parts of the business that I know that we feel good about and we'll see meaningful change year-over-year is in-stores; store operations, presentation, talent and there's been a tremendous amount of activity and upgrade
componenttext:
Rob also keep in mind the other two parts of the business that I know that we feel good about and we'll see meaningful change year-over-year is in-stores; store operations, presentation, talent and there's been a tremendous amount of activity and upgrade going on in that area of the business. And also with the rewards card program heading into holiday as an additional tool to market to customers in addition to the media campaign that Steve mentioned.
And also, I'd remind you, again every retailer will benefit from an extra shopping day between Thanksgiving and Christmas. So we put a fair amount of thought into the fourth quarter when we decided what to tell you guys.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Keith with JMP Securities.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was wondering if you could just comment on the availability of opportunistic closeouts? We've been sharing some anecdotal evidence across retail that inventory is starting to get backed up. So curious to know if you are noticing more phone calls
componenttext: Steve, I was wondering if you could just comment on the availability of opportunistic closeouts? We've been sharing some anecdotal evidence across retail that inventory is starting to get backed up. So curious to know if you are noticing more phone calls starting to come in? And even if you could provide detail on maybe some areas that are particularly robust right now for closeouts?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: It never seems slow. And I know it's very difficult if you're not in the middle of our business to get your head around it. But there is absolutely never a time where we're not getting telephone calls. I will be consistent with what I had said the last fe
componenttext:
It never seems slow. And I know it's very difficult if you're not in the middle of our business to get your head around it. But there is absolutely never a time where we're not getting telephone calls. I will be consistent with what I had said the last few quarters; the deals continue to get larger and larger in size.
And clearly, I can't share them all with you, but you're going to see continued growth from us and just great deals in the DVD part of the business. That just has been terrific for us. We have seen deals that we've never seen before from GPS opportunities and computers, which we never saw really before. The underwear deal was a huge opportunity, and the quantity was enough to take us through the fourth quarter.
The furniture deals, even though it's good business, to me it's what I've said all along. People think that when business is bad that the deals are better, it's not so; it's when business gets better that the deals get better and better and better, because capital investments are made by companies, and comfort levels of trying new and different things which produce this closeout inventory for us. And that's why I think we're seeing bigger and better deals than we've ever seen before.
So if inventories are backing up for manufacturers, you're just telling me that our telephones are going to continue to ring very strong into the third and the fourth quarter. We have ample open-to-buys set aside specifically for closeout deals that are part of our process that I can tell you we haven't had a phone call on yet, but we will in the next week or two weeks or three weeks or four weeks.
The good news about our business is, we don't limit those phone calls just to the fact that we're shut down because it's the fourth quarter or whatever, the first quarter. We have great deals for the first quarter of next year already in place.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the things I noticed was that the gross margin performance in Q2 was particularly impressive. And just in conjunction with the rollback pricing that Wal-Mart was doing in May and June, did you notice any impact into your gross margin from that init
componenttext: One of the things I noticed was that the gross margin performance in Q2 was particularly impressive. And just in conjunction with the rollback pricing that Wal-Mart was doing in May and June, did you notice any impact into your gross margin from that initiative?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're very competitive. We understand 'rollback prices' or whatever price adjustments any retailers do on a district by district basis. We have market managers that are directly responsible in the six regions who are answering to the regional Vice Preside
componenttext:
We're very competitive. We understand 'rollback prices' or whatever price adjustments any retailers do on a district by district basis. We have market managers that are directly responsible in the six regions who are answering to the regional Vice Presidents that are constantly feeding us information, and of course the merchants themselves are constantly out there taking a look at it.
I would tell you, it was quite selective by area of the country and not any specific area, but not nearly on a national basis that all the rhetoric and the verbiage that we have seen it. We absolutely took competitive markdowns where we needed to, but I would tell you they were very small numbers, because we're priced right every day as it is. There may have been a selective district that a store manger at a grocery store or at a national discount retailer decided to take a markdown in Tupelo, Mississippi where we met it.
But there was almost really nothing in the way of pressure on a national basis.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll next hear from Charles Grom with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll next hear from Charles Grom with JPMorgan.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on your third quarter comp guidance of up two to four, and wondering if that's where you're tracking quarter-to-date given that, if my memory is correct that in September and October you had the better months of the quarter last year, comp
componenttext: Just a question on your third quarter comp guidance of up two to four, and wondering if that's where you're tracking quarter-to-date given that, if my memory is correct that in September and October you had the better months of the quarter last year, comping up positive to low single digits. And then, also just wondering if you could comment on the consumable business so far in the third quarter. How has it picked up, and do you believe that the aforementioned Wal-Mart rollback activity hurts you in the second quarter like it did for some other retailers?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a comp standpoint, your memory is correct that post Labor Day last year is when our business turned positive. So August, in the month that we're currently in, we are up against comp store sales declines from a year ago. What I would say is similar to
componenttext:
From a comp standpoint, your memory is correct that post Labor Day last year is when our business turned positive. So August, in the month that we're currently in, we are up against comp store sales declines from a year ago. What I would say is similar to what I talked with a number of people about coming out of Q2. The last 10 or 11 weeks of the quarter in Q2, clearly, you can kind of squeeze our comps for trending in that call it mid-threes range.
As we've turned the corner and headed into third quarter, obviously we're looking at those trends very closely and that's what helps set our guidance. Also, we do have an extra ad here in the month of August as Joe mentioned. So let me just give you quarter-to-date August comps.
I wouldn't be giving you a fair comparison, but what I would say is, we took into account trends coming out of second quarter, beginning of August, and the deals and the promotions that we know we have planned for third quarter, and that's how we landed on the 2% to 4% comp guidance for the quarter. And Steve, you want to talk about consumables?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Consumables is relatively consistent to its performance in the first couple of quarters right now. The basic health and beauty aids, paper, chemicals, home organization parts of the business continues to perform. It's the food piece of the business that's
componenttext:
Consumables is relatively consistent to its performance in the first couple of quarters right now. The basic health and beauty aids, paper, chemicals, home organization parts of the business continues to perform. It's the food piece of the business that's a little bit more challenged to this particular point, although I am encouraged about our plan much more for the fourth quarter than I am for the third quarter. So I hope I responded to that piece.
As far as your comment about Wal-Mart, hurting the market or hurting us, I can only respond to that by saying that 30% of our business is consumables, and of the total company's business, only 10% is food. And if I am not mistaken, Wal-Mart just came off of their fifth quarter in a row of comp store decreases. So I am not so sure that they are doing anything to hurt us or the rest of the market. I guess most of the grocery stores could respond to you a little bit better than I could in that part of the business.
I would tell you that I don't believe that a competitor is hurting us. I as always look at how we are executing that part of the business, and I would admit to you that we are responsible for whatever lack of comp store increase we're having in most of our businesses and not so much what other competitors are doing to us. And we are taking a very hard look at ourselves and seeing what can we do better in those aspects of the business to start the comp increases to be more consistent with the rest of the company.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question was something that Meredith alluded to earlier with regards to your expense structure and given all the changes that you've made and SG&A as a percentage of sales and that was north of 34%, it's now in the mid-31% range. I understand th
componenttext:
My second question was something that Meredith alluded to earlier with regards to your expense structure and given all the changes that you've made and SG&A as a percentage of sales and that was north of 34%, it's now in the mid-31% range. I understand that the fixed costs for '08 was probably flattish in the front half and is going to be up maybe 1% in the back half.
When you look to 2011, as you guys continue to open up more stores and as we get back to a little bit more normalized environment with no distribution cuts and advertising being normal, should we expect your hurdle rate to go up in the future to say maybe 1% or 2% rate down the road? And then in addition, what do you guys think about the gross profit margin outlook, because somewhere in SG&A, your GPM has been a curve over the past couple of years?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: As usual, we start getting questions on the next year about this time of year. We'll speak the specifics about 2011 in March of next year. We have been pretty consistent to say that our internal goal, and this is a very strong internal goal of ours, is to
componenttext:
As usual, we start getting questions on the next year about this time of year. We'll speak the specifics about 2011 in March of next year. We have been pretty consistent to say that our internal goal, and this is a very strong internal goal of ours, is to continue to expand the operating margin each year and in general that is expected to occur through SG&A leverage.
Do we believe a flat comp as a leverage point will continue for ever? And we've said no, but that is an ongoing goal. So we will continue to strive to find ways to save expenses and continue to keep that leverage point as low as possible. But we are going to continue with store growth plans. So next year, we've said that we'd like to open a few more stores than this year. And to your point, Chuck, that does put some pressure on that leverage point.
Gross margin, we've said that our fourth quarter this year is a perfect example. We'll never manage gross margin rate at the expensive of gross margin dollars. So we always look at expanding gross margin dollars, which we are doing in the fourth quarter this year, and not manage to the gross margin rate. But in general, our goal is to keep maintained our gross margin rate and expand our operating margin for SG&A leverage.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up on the D&A line. Just wondering why it came down. I think you were formally forecasting $80 million to $85 million and now it's going to be $80 million. Maybe you could give us a little bit of color on what you think the number wi
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up on the D&A line. Just wondering why it came down. I think you were formally forecasting $80 million to $85 million and now it's going to be $80 million. Maybe you could give us a little bit of color on what you think the number will look like next year.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think in the prepared comments what we mentioned is that's principally timing of new stores, the new stores we had anticipated opening a little earlier and they're being now opened later in the third quarter and actually a few to open in the fourth quar
componenttext: I think in the prepared comments what we mentioned is that's principally timing of new stores, the new stores we had anticipated opening a little earlier and they're being now opened later in the third quarter and actually a few to open in the fourth quarter. So that's the principle reason for the lower depreciation.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have not changed our CapEx guidance for the year, Chuck. We have just moved it to later in the year. So that has had a corresponding impact on depreciation.
componenttext: Yes, we have not changed our CapEx guidance for the year, Chuck. We have just moved it to later in the year. So that has had a corresponding impact on depreciation.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will take our final question from Mark Mandel with ThinkEquity.
componenttext: We will take our final question from Mark Mandel with ThinkEquity.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that you expect lower initial markups on some fourth quarter deals. How do reconcile that with the point that you made earlier, Steve, about the abundance of solid deals that you are seeing.
componenttext: You mentioned that you expect lower initial markups on some fourth quarter deals. How do reconcile that with the point that you made earlier, Steve, about the abundance of solid deals that you are seeing.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is a big difference between the abundance of the deals and the markup on the deals and of course where we're buying in them in the classifications that we do. We have deals that we do in the 30s. We have deals we do in the 40s, and we have deals tha
componenttext:
There is a big difference between the abundance of the deals and the markup on the deals and of course where we're buying in them in the classifications that we do. We have deals that we do in the 30s. We have deals we do in the 40s, and we have deals that we do in the 50s.
And I will reiterate my comments, because markup is only a function of what you're charging on a piece of merchandize. We are much more focused on gross margin dollars, incremental gross margin dollars.
So if we get an abundance of additional deals going forward into the fourth quarter and we think incrementally they can add gross margin dollars to our business. Whether they're in the 30s or the 40s or not, we're not going to try to play to the market to a number. We're going to take advantage of the great values our customers respond to and incrementally add gross margin dollars that could potentially affect the overall gross margin percent for the quarter.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, I believe you mentioned the list that you get from sales from store upgrades and so on, can you give us some idea what the investment is and the what the return on investment is in some of those projects?
componenttext: Joe, I believe you mentioned the list that you get from sales from store upgrades and so on, can you give us some idea what the investment is and the what the return on investment is in some of those projects?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's too early, I think I'd like to reserve specific lifts on those until our next call. We're about a little over half way through the process, I think we've done 70 or so, a little over 100 stores. But in general, there is slight disruption duri
componenttext: I think it's too early, I think I'd like to reserve specific lifts on those until our next call. We're about a little over half way through the process, I think we've done 70 or so, a little over 100 stores. But in general, there is slight disruption during the re-way and then the lifts occur post re-way. So there's two parts to that story, and as I said, since we're pretty early on will differ actual results. But we've said that we're pleased, we do believe that it's store-by-store, we'd like to think, there's a large number of stores that we could do in future years. But we're pleased with the results today with exact specific. So I will differ.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 24, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our initial guidance for the year, Mark, that we're going to spend about $5 million of capital on the store refresh program, so ballpark 105 stores gets you a little less than $50,000 per store. So clearly, there's not a tremendous amount of lift neede
componenttext: In our initial guidance for the year, Mark, that we're going to spend about $5 million of capital on the store refresh program, so ballpark 105 stores gets you a little less than $50,000 per store. So clearly, there's not a tremendous amount of lift needed to make that a good project from a financial standpoint, not to mention the positive impact that has with the customer and also store associates.
