headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Big Lots Third Quarter 2010 Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to introduce today's first speaker, Vice President of Strategic Planning and Investor Relations, Tim Johnson.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Big Lots Third Quarter 2010 Teleconference. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to introduce today's first speaker, Vice President of Strategic Planning and Investor Relations, Tim Johnson.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Katie and thank you everyone for joining us for our third quarter conference call. With me here in Columbus today are Steve Fishman, our Chairman and CEO; Joe Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and Chuck Haubiel, Executiv
componenttext:
Thanks, Katie and thank you everyone for joining us for our third quarter conference call. With me here in Columbus today are Steve Fishman, our Chairman and CEO; Joe Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and Chuck Haubiel, Executive Vice President Real Estate, Legal and General Counsel.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind you that any forward-looking statements we make on today's call involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to our Safe Harbor provisions, as stated in our press release and our SEC filing, and that actual results can differ materially from those described in our forward-looking statement. As discussed in this morning's release, our results for the third quarter and year-to-date periods of fiscal 2009 included an item in continuing operations that we believe was not directly related to the company's ongoing operations.
We have provided a non-GAAP reconciliation for both periods last year and those schedules are attached to today's release. Since we do not view this item as relevant to the ongoing operations of the business, the balance of our prepared comments and comparisons this morning will be based on non-GAAP results from continuing operations.
With that, I'll turn it over to Steve.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks TJ, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, our customers continued to be selective in their purchases but were to spend money where they saw a tremendous values as evidenced by the continued strength in certain of our higher ticket,
componenttext:
Thanks TJ, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, our customers continued to be selective in their purchases but were to spend money where they saw a tremendous values as evidenced by the continued strength in certain of our higher ticket, discretionary categories. From a merchandising perspective, Furniture, Seasonal and Home continue to lead the way. 
For the fourth consecutive quarter, Furniture comped up double digits with a very solid execution across all classifications. In particular Upholstery was excellent Stratolounger closeout deal and the Furniture Roadshow supplemented by solid performance in our day in and day out assortment. Closeout deals are a nice shot in the arm when we get them but the real strength is our everyday assortment at a value and quality level that makes us an industry leader in the low to moderate price point furniture business.
Our Seasonal category comped up high single digits for the second quarter in a row. Lawn & Garden particularly our tailgating assortment was strong early in the quarter and each of our fall Seasonal business has comped up mid-to high singles. And there I'm referring to Halloween, harvest and early Christmas selling. Again, this is one of the higher price points in the store, further reinforcing to us that we're presenting great value and we think this bodes well for the holiday season.
Home comped up in the low single digits, on top of improving trends from a year ago so comp-on-comp which I believe is an indicator of category gaining momentum. Results were driven by a combination of good deals and improving quality on consistency product. 
We experienced improving trends in some of our hardlines classifications like tools, appliances and home maintenance, offset by a slight decline in our Electronics business as we anniversaried the very successful launch of our videogame software program a year ago. Our most challenged business was Consumables, where we comped down in the low single digits. For those of you who have followed us for a while, you know that we don't make excuses for our performance. In this situation, I don't believe we executed as well as we're capable off and did not provide the customer with the offering that they've come to expect from us. The team is working very hard and swiftly to make changes to prepare us for the new year.
So we posted a positive comp for Q3 but we always want to do better. Having said that, clearly, there's some very encouraging performances in the third quarter. Now Joe's going to give you some details on the quarter and how we're looking at our forward guidance. Joe?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Steve and good morning, everyone. Sales for the third quarter were $1.056 billion, an increase of 2.0% over the $1.035 billion we reported for the third quarter of last year. Comparable store sales increased 3.7%.For Q3, operating profit d
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Steve and good morning, everyone. Sales for the third quarter were $1.056 billion, an increase of 2.0% over the $1.035 billion we reported for the third quarter of last year. Comparable store sales increased 3.7%.
For Q3, operating profit dollars were $27 million come, a decrease of approximately $8 million compared to last year's gross margin growth. Gross margin dollar growth was offset by an increase in expense dollar. In terms of gross margin our dollars grew by approximately $10 million or 2.4% due to a combination of total sales growth and expansion in the gross margin rate. Our rate for Q3 of 40.5% was 10 basis points above last year and better than our guidance. The rate increase was due to lower markdowns, lower shrink costs and a slightly favorable mix impact. In particular the favorable merchandise mix impact on lower markdowns were the direct result of better performance in certain of our discretionary categories particularly Seasonal and Home. These improvements were partially offset by higher freight costs, both domestic and import.
Total expense dollars were $401 million, an increase of $18 million or approximately 5% compared to last year. We believe there were certain unique factors in the third quarter and we do expect expense leverage to return in the fourth quarter. During Q3, we were able to flex down certain expenses to match our lower-than-expected sales base. However, we continue to make the necessary investments to open new stores, refresh existing stores and prepare for the all-important Q4 holiday selling season. 
In terms of new stores, we opened 55 new stores from August through November compared to 33 new stores during the same timeframe last year. And with the additional 22 new store openings came incremental costs, payroll, occupancy training supplies transportation and obviously as you can see from our P&L, higher depreciation on those new assets.
We also completed this year's class of refreshed stores during Q3 which was incremental activity to last year and there was some associated costs. And finally, maybe the most important element that makes Q3 unique from our focus was our focus on preparing for the holiday selling season. Heavy shipments of goods processed from our DC stores a more planful approach to setting foreceps and endcaps and hiring seasonal associates to help with the workload and all of those costs were incurred during Q3 in advance of the significant spike in sales we experienced in November and December.
Net interest expense was $0.7 million for the quarter compared to $0.5 million last year. Our tax rate for the third quarter of fiscal 2010 was 32.3% compared to 35.2% last year with the lower tax rate principally due to higher tax credit in certain jurisdictions. In total for the third quarter fiscal 2010, we reported income from continuing operations of $17.7 million or $0.23 per diluted share compared to income from continuing operations of $22.1 million or $0.27 per diluted share a year ago. This result was below our previously communicated guidance of $0.25 to $0.29. At a high level the shortfall to the model was top line-driven, partially offset by better-than-expected gross margin performance and a slight positive impact in both the tax rate and share count. 
Our original guidance called for our Q3 SG&A rate to be flattish to last year, principally due to the investments in holiday preparation I indicated before. The expense deleverage not included in our original guidance was principally due to the shortfall in sales. Expenses flexed as expected on a lower sales base but not to the extent of the planned SG&A rate. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Inventory ended the third quarter fiscal 2010 at $1.006 billion compared to $918 million last year. Of the $88 million increase to last year approximately $75 million was inventory to support higher store count and the intentional decision to move up delivery dates and bring import merchandise in early to avoid potential disruption that could have resulted from the container shortages coming out of Asia.
Inventory levels were up 6% per store when considering stores open at the end of the quarter and stores open in the month of November. We view this level of increase as timing related and would expect our inventory per store at the end of the fourth quarter to be flat to slightly up to last year. 
Cash flow which we define as cash provided by operating activities less cash used in investing activities decreased by $89 million for the quarter compared to last year. This is largely attributable to the timing of inventory flow that I mentioned earlier and the higher CapEx related to new stores.
We ended the quarter with $51 million of cash and cash equivalents and $129 million of borrowings under our credit facility compared to $46 million of cash and cash equivalents and $1 million of borrowings under our credit facility last year. The increased level of borrowings is directly related to the share repurchase activity and fiscal 2010 and increased inventory investment due to timing is a mentioned earlier partially offset by cash generated by operations over the past 12 months.
During Q3, we invested $108 million to opportunistically for just 3.5 million shares at a weighted average price of $31.15 per share. Year-to-date, we've repurchased opportunistically $192 million of stock or 6.0 million shares at a weighted average price of $32.16 per share. You may also recall that we executed $150 million accelerated share repurchase program or ASR in March of this year although the final settlement of the total number of shares repurchased under our ASR or will not be known until the contract ends. Had the ASR settled at the end of our fiscal third quarter the total amount of shares repurchased under the ASR would have been 4.4 million shares. Combining our opportunistic activity with an assumed ASR of 4.4 million shares, our total number of shares repurchased year-to-date would be 10.4 million or approximately 13% of our outstanding shares at the beginning of fiscal 2010.
We currently have $58 million remaining under our current authorization to repurchase shares opportunistically in the open market as of today. For the third quarter, capital expenditures totaled $41 million compared to $23 million last year with the increase of $18 million primarily focused on new stores, refreshed stores and investments in energy management systems for our stores. Depreciation expense for the quarter was $19.6 million, an increase of $1.4 million, corresponding with the significant investments made in our business over the last 12 months.
Moving on to guidance, we are forecasting a total sales increase of 4% to 6% for the fourth quarter. This level of increase correlates to total sales of between $1.52 billion to $1.55 billion and is based on comparable store sales in the range of flat to up 2% supplemented by some very successful new store performance which Chuck will touch on in a moment. Additionally, we expect to benefit from one additional shopping day between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Consistent with our prior guidance we expect the fourth quarter gross margin rate will be below last year due to higher domestic and import freight costs as well as lower IMU in certain deals and holiday strategies designed to drive excitement and foot traffic to our stores. From an expense standpoint in Q4, we still anticipate leverage in most major expense areas including store payroll, distribution and transportation, utilities and advertising. This favorability is assumed to be partially offset by higher debit card fees resulting from rate hikes being passed on by network providers. Based on these assumptions, Q4 EPS from continuing operations is now estimated to be in the range of $1.36 to $1.42 per diluted share compared to $1.31 per diluted share last year. 
For the full year we now expect income from continuing operations for fiscal 2010 to be in the range of $2.75 to $2.81 per diluted share which I believe is consistent with the most recent first call consensus estimates.
This compares to our previous guidance of $2.82 to $2.90 per diluted share with the variance directly attributable with softer sales in third quarter which are assumed to continue through the fourth quarter. This range of EPS assumes an average annual diluted share count of approximately 79 million shares and does not contemplate any utilization of the $58 million remaining under our current share repurchase authorization. We now estimate our inventory turnover at 3.7x, cash flow of approximately $200 million and net interest expense of approximately $2 million. For the full year of fiscal 2010 we expect the comparable store sales increase in the range of 3.0% to 3.5%. Now I'll turn it over to Chuck for an update on Real Estate.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Cooper. During the third quarter we opened 28 new stores and closed 15 stores leaving us with 1389 stores and total selling square footage of 29.9 million at the end of the quarter. Subsequent to the end of Q3, we opened an additional 27 ne
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Cooper. During the third quarter we opened 28 new stores and closed 15 stores leaving us with 1389 stores and total selling square footage of 29.9 million at the end of the quarter. Subsequent to the end of Q3, we opened an additional 27 new stores in November bringing our total openings for the year to 80 stores.
Of the 80 store openings 33 were new A-type locations with the balance in more traditional centers. Year-to-date we've closed 26 stores and anticipate closing 16 more stores in Q4, bringing the total for the year to 42 closings in fiscal 2010. Of the closings, 23 are actually relocations and are either order stores being relocated to higher traffic areas in better strip centers or stores previously too small for a full-size furniture department being relegated to a larger space accommodate our full Furniture assortment. As Joe mentioned we've been very encouraged by the performance of our new stores opened this year. For new stores with enough history to trend we're forecasting annualized sales above our initial plans both in terms of dollars and productivity per foot. Clearly, we're finding and securing better sites to open but a large portion of this success is attributed to better store opening process beginning to end from merchandising to marketing to allocation of product through to store operations.
In terms of the A-type locations, we continue to be pleased with the performance to date which has validated our decision to move aggressively into better locations. Additionally, as we've said on a number of occasions we believe we're attracting a meaningful amount of new customers to our A-store format, customers who have may not shopped at Big Lots in the past or have a store in their normal shipping pattern. Our traditional locations are trending better than we anticipated even though this locations are not classified as an A-type locations it's fair to say that a large majority of these stores are in better locations than we may have opened the past. In particular both A-type and traditional stores opened in October and November have experienced a significant surge in business by combining grand opening activity along with the natural spike in holiday traffic we experienced in our stores during the fourth quarter. Now back to Steve for some closing remarks.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So hopefully that gives you a very clear idea for results expectations for the fourth quarter and an update on the real estate activity. Our total sales forecast for the Q4 of 46% would represent some very good performance on top of our record quarter a y
componenttext: So hopefully that gives you a very clear idea for results expectations for the fourth quarter and an update on the real estate activity. Our total sales forecast for the Q4 of 46% would represent some very good performance on top of our record quarter a year ago. There are several encouraging trends which could impact not only holiday but also highlight longer-term opportunities for the company. First and foremost in merchandising early customer response to our nine weeks of Christmas strategies has been pretty solid. In particular, the comp strengthen Furniture Seasonal and Home has continued on into Q4 as has the improvements in certain of our hardlines categories. Early selling in toys has been very competitive which was not unexpected but we have sufficient dry powder to be aggressive. The merchandising strategies focused on key items in our how high is high testing are validating to us that we are on the right path. In terms of stores from my visits I do believe our execution continues to improve our stores are becoming easier to shop, our merchants have delivered more floor-ready merchandise and PDQs to help in presentation and more attracting a more talented team to Big Lots. From a marketing perspective we're now approaching 7 million Rewards club members and our testing efforts are well underway to understand what generates the best and most productive response from our customers taken And I feel particularly good about our direction in Real Estate and the sales volume we're experiencing with some of our new locations It reinforces that new stores are likely to be the best investments we're making right now for the future of the company. Store growth is at the top of the priority list for allocation of capital. With that I'll turn it back to TJ.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Casey would like to go ahead and open up the lines for questions now.
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. Casey would like to go ahead and open up the lines for questions now.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] To start with our first question from Jeff Stein with Soleil Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] To start with our first question from Jeff Stein with Soleil Securities.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for you on the Toy business. We've been looking at your circulars this year relative to last then in particular you are advertising some in-season toys where in certainly over Black Friday you were undercut by Wal-Mart and I'm just trying to unde
componenttext: Question for you on the Toy business. We've been looking at your circulars this year relative to last then in particular you are advertising some in-season toys where in certainly over Black Friday you were undercut by Wal-Mart and I'm just trying to understand a little bit better what your strategy is on in-season toys and if you are going to be in that business, don't you believe it's important to be competitive on like items?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is yes. I think you're alluding to one or two items that Wal-Mart undercut us. We certainly don't should be undercut by competition. We don't go into the season job planning to do that. We thought some of those same brand items and you're speak
componenttext: The answer is yes. I think you're alluding to one or two items that Wal-Mart undercut us. We certainly don't should be undercut by competition. We don't go into the season job planning to do that. We thought some of those same brand items and you're speaking specifically on the paper jam and susu pet which by the way we had a complete sellout on, that our intention is not to be undercut. We've always been a leader not only in toys but in every product category that we're in. We've taken and reacted to all the pricing that we felt we needed to adjust and I think if you're in our stores today you'll find we're more aggressive than we potentially were over that weekend on a couple of those key items and even more items I think you'll find one of the interesting things about our marketing businesses is that we can work very close to the vest and in fact we went through the Thanksgiving weekend we were still able to react to the last week of December piece before Christmas and make any kind of adjustments that we needed to make. So along with the fact that you are going to see us extremely aggressive in print in the next four weeks you're also going to see us extremenly aggressive online. If you're a rewards member we have done some really unique things all along the way we planned on testing and finding out some of the things that really will excite our Rewards members but we can react on a day-to-day basis by putting items up online and changing prices and you're going to see that throughout the balance of the Christmas season.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from David Mann from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from David Mann from Johnson Rice.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you address a little bit what's going on in Consumables in terms of what you think you need to do Is it a function of getting some additional vendors changing categories and how long do you think it will take to improve that business especially since
componenttext: Can you address a little bit what's going on in Consumables in terms of what you think you need to do Is it a function of getting some additional vendors changing categories and how long do you think it will take to improve that business especially since it's such a fast turner?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I hope it starts to improve as soon as possible. I would tell you David and I kind of spoke to it on the last conference call and I would speak to it again today that although we're concerned always about businesses but are having what we consider t
componenttext: Well, I hope it starts to improve as soon as possible. I would tell you David and I kind of spoke to it on the last conference call and I would speak to it again today that although we're concerned always about businesses but are having what we consider to be challenges. The food part of our business is probably the thing that I'm most focused. It's the single most important business out of all the Consumables and about 10% of our total business on a normal year. The good news is that in the fourth quarter Consumables isn't as near a percent to total as it is in the first three quarters of the year. And we're cranking on cylinders on the businesses that we eed to be cranking on into the fourth quarter right now. But you're going to see a lot of newness and a lot of change in our food business coming in to the first quarter. I really can't speak to it yet and don't want too but there's going to be a lot of creativity, a lot of newness and a lot of excitement on the things that are selling in this particular point. If you go through the stores a lot of the specialty foods that we really keyed into for Christmas right now. They're doing well. It's the day in and day out business I think we're not the only ones struggling. I may be wrong about this. And again you guys know the business a lot better than I do, but the guys who have Consumables, particularly the discount has a very hight percent total. In the last five or six quarters have struggled a lot more than we have on the top line of our business and our consumables business particularly food is much as double what it is in our business. So I don't know that we're the only one struggling. The consumers are feeling a pinch. Prices are up across the board. One of the things that I wanted to make sure of is that our customer knows that even though prices are going up at other major discounters and grocery stores that there's still that price-value relationship and that distance between us and anybody else in that 10% to 50% savings rate and I think we're working very hard to understand that piece of it, too. So we're pretty consumed with all of Consumables. There's still a lot of great deals out there. There's still great deals in the stores There's still going to be great deals going into January and in the fourth quarter that we're working on all the time and the consumer products companies are coming to us constantly on. So I'm encouraged what I think we're capable of doing going into the first quarter.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Dan Wewer with Raymond James.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, just to follow up on that, if you look at the other small box value retailers let's say Family Dollar, Dollar General, they've actually been calling you out Consumables as being their top-performing category the last few years I mean there does see
componenttext: Steve, just to follow up on that, if you look at the other small box value retailers let's say Family Dollar, Dollar General, they've actually been calling you out Consumables as being their top-performing category the last few years I mean there does seem to be demand for that business but Do you think there's a risk that a retail format that focuses on closeouts and treasure hunts maybe doesn't work for that day in day out customer You're thinking about the mom in the van with two kids and she has 10 to 15 minutes to shop She needs to know that certain brands are always in the store?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's two separate customers Dan and I'll tell you what I think about that. Number one, from a location standpoint, I have said and I would say again that I believe although the dollar stores are doing a great job of executing, the dollar
componenttext: Well, I think there's two separate customers Dan and I'll tell you what I think about that. Number one, from a location standpoint, I have said and I would say again that I believe although the dollar stores are doing a great job of executing, the dollar stores are kind of like the convenient store of choice today and I think probably the major big-box retailers would say the same thing to you. Although I think theyre doing great job I think theyre experiencing the fact that the challenged economic consumer has only x amount of money to spend and it's easier to go into a local dollar store and pick up that $8, $9, $10, $11, $12 worth of what I need today and what I can afford groceries versus how we execute a strategy or some of the traditional retailers or grocery stores do. I don't think that it's not a strategy that's not important to us that we'll continue to one. Of the things that's different between our customers and the customer that you alluded to is that our average customer spends as much as 35 minutes in our store So they don't come to us for a quick pick-up and a quick shop. That could be challenging to us today. But in the long run, we'll still do a lot of Consumables business and we'll still be a great place to come to for the best values you can possibly find.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you ever be open to the idea of perhaps reducing the space committed to Consumables and reallocating back to the other discretionary categories where you been achieving a lot of success?
componenttext: Would you ever be open to the idea of perhaps reducing the space committed to Consumables and reallocating back to the other discretionary categories where you been achieving a lot of success?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We constantly are challenging ourselves for our space allocation but I would tell you I like our space allocation in Consumables. Because we're struggling right now in a particular category doesn't mean that we're going to throw in the towel and the baby
componenttext: We constantly are challenging ourselves for our space allocation but I would tell you I like our space allocation in Consumables. Because we're struggling right now in a particular category doesn't mean that we're going to throw in the towel and the baby out with the water, bathwater I think think we run a great Consumables business I think we have been focused and executed slightly the way that we have in the past in the way of showing great deals to our customer and we'll get back on course. But I don't think we're overspaced in Consumables right now and I will tell you that there are other businesses that I think that we challenged ourselves that we might be overspaced and we have already reduced some of the other highly competitive plastics space in the last 12 months and reallocated it to pets and are getting a great return on investment. And without speaking before we have a really good plan I think you're going to see a shift in some of our businesses going into next fall. In some of the businesses we continue to grow at a faster pace and are very successful and seasonal I mean we absolutely know that we need to expand our Seasonal space in the third and the fourth quarter next year I think we do a pretty good job in the first and second quarter in Lawn & Garden and Trim and that's clearly going to come out of some businesses that are underperforming right now but I'd rather not speak to that until we have a really solid plan in place, maybe in another quarter or two.

componenttext: Question about free cash flow and soft product, it looks like in the latest quarter you took advantage of a low stock price and borrowed under the revolver to buy stock. You may not have a lot left under your volume but would you continue to be opportunistic? I'm going to guess that you get very cash rich by the time the holiday is over you can pay down the revolver. But would you borrow more to buy back stock now?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. We did have some borrowings under the revolver during the third quarter but we anticipate under the current share repurchase program by the end of the year we would be out of the revolver. And certainly look at we're not afraid to leverage th
componenttext: This is Joe. We did have some borrowings under the revolver during the third quarter but we anticipate under the current share repurchase program by the end of the year we would be out of the revolver. And certainly look at we're not afraid to leverage the business. Obviously, that's cheap right now but that's a topic that each quarter we take up with the board and partner with them on to what extent we execute future share repurchases So at this point, can't address it but we do have $58 million left on the current share repurchase plan and we'll address that with the board.

componenttext: Well as we've shown in the past, when it's appropriate, we will borrow to execute any capital investment or share repurchase when we feel that's the right thing to do. But at this point, I can't speak to that and that's something that we partner with our Board of Directors on.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think I was probably alluding to the Toy business Meredith and I wanted to be very specific and I tried to make that clear in my comments I guess I didn't but I guess reiterating that to you we have a lot of dry powder. We do a pretty good job of
componenttext: Well, I think I was probably alluding to the Toy business Meredith and I wanted to be very specific and I tried to make that clear in my comments I guess I didn't but I guess reiterating that to you we have a lot of dry powder. We do a pretty good job of going into the season knowing we are going to have to get aggressive somewhere for one reason or another and markdowns are more than adequate in the budget at this particular point to take care of it. The only challenge to the fourth quarter from a margin standpoint that I think Joe alluded to in his comments is predominantly, the freight part of the business, the inbound and the outbound freight and then of course the IMU. I mean we've taken a very aggressive stance in a couple of categories that we think it's the right thing to do to get through the quarter. We're still going to make a lot of money in the fourth quarter and feel pretty comfortable with the guidance that we gave.

componenttext:
Well, I will comment on a few of them. And by the way we continue to do raise the ring and how high is high in this Christmas to just because we did it last Christmas We made some major investments in a couple of categories that I would tell you is doing quite well and I'll speak to maybe three areas. Number one is fireplace. And we really went after the fireplace business This is the third year in a row that we think we dominate the best value out there in that business and that is doing quite well is partially indicative of what happened in the third quarter in the Furniture business although Furniture crossed the space and all four of the businesses were good. That was very exciting. I will tell you that we had a good Thanksgiving weekend. We were really pleased with the Thanksgiving weekend and that had a lot to do with how high is high because we had an exceptional three-day Thanksgiving weekend a year ago and to be able to comp-on-comp 
on those two three big days of the year, maybe the three biggest days of the year although I have to go back and verify that so don't hold me to that. We are really pleased. Fireplace, I just dropped my In Home, particularly some of the better goods that we tested how high is high blankets, microfiber things like that in the $15 to $20 range that did quite well and there was a third issue I wanted to talk to you about and I just went blank. Seasonal, trim-a-tree particularly in the lighting business where we were testing how high is high. And I think I alluded in the last quarterly call that how we were really encouraged about what we thought we could do in Christmas trees and we kept challenging ourselves on how high is high there and the fact that there's a lot of changes in the lighting business that we are in to that business or a great customer. Everybody needs new LED lighting this year and those investments have proven so far to this point to be really good investments in how high is high testing.

componenttext: It's Chuck Haubiel. Just a couple of things on that. Number one, I think you followed us you have to realize that we will do whatever we think is in the best interest with respect to investing capital. He's been very clear about a desire to increase our accelerate store growth once we have everything in place and one of the things that we're trying to convey during this call is that as our team gets stronger and we have stronger leadership in the field, we are interested in doing everything we can to make sure that we're growing at a rate that we are very comfortable with not trying to get a number but in fact making sure that every one of the stores that we opened meet or exceed if you will what we believe they should be able to perform at that level of. We haven't given our numbers for next year yet. We'll do that in March during the fourth quarter call for next year but it is something that we debate literally on a week-by-week or day-by-day basis.

componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Joe. I'll start and Chuck can jump. But we've indicated that we've certainly been pleased and encouraged by the performance of the A stores. As you mentioned eight opened in 2009 So we only have a few stores that had been opened for a full ye
componenttext: Yes, this is Joe. I'll start and Chuck can jump. But we've indicated that we've certainly been pleased and encouraged by the performance of the A stores. As you mentioned eight opened in 2009 So we only have a few stores that had been opened for a full year. As we've gone through 2010 and opened 30 or so, what we've learned is an A store all A stores aren't going to be the same and some of them, it's an A store in the market where they reside. So we can't have an A store with company average volume but it would be higher average volume than the surrounding market. And we can also have A stores that you've seen our a store Polaris in Columbus where it performs significantly above company average. So it's an A based on location. Does it have co-tenants that can help draw traffic. Does it have population density. Those kind of attributes so we have been very pleased but beyond the A stores we've been pleased with what we call the traditional stores that we've opened in 2010. And what shocks team and the finance team is working together to the turbine is that really what are the key attributes that have been driving that success and how can we replicate it with that one necessarily start ramping up store growth and assumes that all new stores are going to produce like they did in 2010. But if you from a modeling standpoint when you see the spread between total sales and comp store sales, you can tell that there's been a little that the new stores are now becoming productive. That's encouraging to us. As sad we do want to be delivered as we open new stores we want to make sure we develop the talent in the field that can support the new store openings and also that economics of the new stores continued to be favorable for the profitability of the company.

componenttext: John, this is TJ I'll start and then have Joe fill in the blanks with me. But overall the net number of new stores opened next year and the year after growth from where we are today. In looking at some of the more recent store openings, it is fairly recent as we just said but I guess what we're encouraged by John normal new store be in the early read initial lease term of five to seven years are we delivering a good return or are we delivering a return close store better than our airport average weighted cost of capital which we estimate loosely to be around 12%. componenttext: What we are assuming is we did as a Steve and TJ both mansion we had a great good week for in November we have a good Thanksgiving week but our flat to 2% guidance what that represents is fairly consistent performance through week for of December and then you have an extra shopping day. So take out week for November and kind of run through pretty consistent weeks one two and three in November and then the first part of December when we talked about we've seen some improvement in November that's really off September and October. It's not necessarily we're not projecting significant improvement off the third quarter trend it's just that we saw a slowdown coming out of August But when you look at the 0.7% for the third quarter, that's a three-month comp obviously. August, we outperformed that in September and October we saw some softening which we've seen some improvement over those two months trend in November and we are encouraged by that pic what we are looking at very, very closely right now is how our shoppers shopping after the Black Friday weekend and week one of December and week two of December are very, very important there to see how strong will they come back in the stores after-tax pretty successful weekend across retail that just Big Lots. So we believe our comps comp guidance is the best we no today and then of course we roll in the January where we have a very strong January of 2010 and your comping on top of that now our assortment going in there since very compelling, we are very encouraged by it but there's a lot of sales ahead of us hence our guidance.

componenttext: So I guess it's a fair summary, August was good, slowdown to flattish in September and October, a little bit of improvement in early November with strong Black Friday weekend and basically assuming a little get back early December but the extra day getting us into that 0% to 2% range.
