headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Big Lots third quarter 2010 teleconference. This call is being recorded. During this session, all lines will be muted until the question-and-answer portion of the call.At this time, I would like to introduce today's
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Big Lots third quarter 2010 teleconference. This call is being recorded. During this session, all lines will be muted until the question-and-answer portion of the call.
At this time, I would like to introduce today's first speaker, Vice President of Strategic Planning and Investor Relations, Tim Johnson.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Katie and thank you everyone for joining us for our third quarter conference call. With me here in Columbus today are Steve Fishman, our Chairman and CEO; Joe Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Chuck Haubiel, Executi
componenttext:
Thanks, Katie and thank you everyone for joining us for our third quarter conference call. With me here in Columbus today are Steve Fishman, our Chairman and CEO; Joe Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Chuck Haubiel, Executive Vice President, Real Estate, Legal and General Counsel.
Before we get started, I'd like to remind you that any forward-looking statements we make on today's call involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to our Safe Harbor provisions as stated in our press release and in our SEC filings, and that actual results can differ materially from those described in our forward-looking statements.
As discussed in this morning's release, our results for the third quarter and year-to-date periods of fiscal 2009 included in items and continuing operations that we believe was not directly related to the company's ongoing operations. We have provided a non-GAAP reconciliation for both periods last year and those schedules are attached to today's release. Since we do not view this item as relevant to ongoing operations of the business, the balance of our prepared comments and comparisons this morning will be based on the non-GAAP results from continuing operations.
With that, Ill turn it over to Steve.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks T.J., and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, our customers continued to be selective in their purchases, but were willing to spend money where they saw tremendous values as evidenced by the continued strength in certain of our higher
componenttext:
Thanks T.J., and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, our customers continued to be selective in their purchases, but were willing to spend money where they saw tremendous values as evidenced by the continued strength in certain of our higher ticket discretionary categories.
From a merchandising perspective, furniture, seasonal and home continued to lead the way. For the fourth consecutive quarter furniture comped up double digits with a very solid execution across all classifications. In particular, upholstery was excellent, Stratolounger closeout deal and the furniture road show supplemented by solid performance and our day in and day out assortment.
Close out deals are a nice shot in the arm when we get them, but the real strength is our everyday assortment at a value and quality level that makes us an industry leader in the low to moderate price point furniture business.
Our seasonal category comped up high single digits for the second quarter in a row. Lawn and garden, particularly our tailgating assortment was strong early in the quarter, and each of our fall seasonal businesses comped up mid to high singles. There Im referring to Halloween, Harvest and early Christmas selling. Again, this is one of the higher price points in the store, further reinforcing to us that were presenting great value and we think this bodes well for the holiday season.
Home comped up in the low single digits on top of improving trends from a year ago. So comp on comp, which I believe is an indicator, a category gaining momentum. Results were driven by a combination of good deals and improving quality on consistency product.
We experienced improving trends in some of our hardlines classifications like tools, appliances and home maintenance offset by a slight decline in our electronics business, as we anniversaried the very successful launch of our video game software program a year ago.
Our most challenged business was consumables, where we comped down in the low single digits.
For those of you who have followed us for a while, you know that we don't make excuses for our performance. In this situation, I don't believe we executed as well as we're capable of, and did not provide the customer with the offering that they've come to expect from us. The team is working very hard and swiftly to make changes to prepare us for the New Year. So we posted a positive comp for Q3, but we always want to do better. Having said that, clearly there are some very encouraging performances in the third quarter.
Now, Joe is going to give you some details on the quarter, and how we're looking at our forward guidance. Joe?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve and good morning, everyone. Sales for the third quarter were $1.056 billion, an increase of 2.0%, over the $1.035 billion we reported for the third quarter of last year. Comparable store sales increased 0.7%.For Q3 operating profit dollars
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve and good morning, everyone. Sales for the third quarter were $1.056 billion, an increase of 2.0%, over the $1.035 billion we reported for the third quarter of last year. Comparable store sales increased 0.7%.
For Q3 operating profit dollars were $27 million, a decrease of approximately $8 million compared to last year's gross margin growth - gross margin dollar growth was offset by an increase in expense dollars. In terms of gross margin our dollars grew by approximately $10 million, or 2.4% due to a combination of total sales growth and expansion in the gross margin rate.
Our rate for Q3 up 40.5% was 10 basis points above last year and better than our guidance. The rate increase was due to lower markdowns, lower shrink costs and a slightly favorable mix impact. In particular, the favorable merchandise mix impact in lower markdowns were the direct result of better performance in certain of our discretionary categories, particularly seasonal and home. These improvements were partially offset by higher freight costs both domestic and import.
Total expense dollars were $401 million, an increase of $18 million or approximately 5% compared to last year. We believe there were certain unique factors in the third quarter and we do expect to expense leverage to return in the fourth quarter.
During Q3, we were able to flex down certain expenses to match our lower than expected sales base, however we continued to make the necessary investments to open new stores, refresh existing stores and prepare for the all important Q4 holiday selling season.
In terms of new stores, we opened 55 new stores from August through November compared to 33 new stores during the same timeframe last year, and with the additional 22 new store openings came incremental costs, payroll, occupancy, training, supplies, transportation and obviously as you can see from our P&L higher depreciation on those new assets. We also completed this years class of refresh stores during Q3 which was incremental activity to last year and there were some associated costs.
Finally, may be the most important element that makes Q3 unique from our focus was our focus on preparing for the holiday selling season. Heavy shipments of goods process from our DC Store stores are more planful approach to setting floor sets and encaps and hiring seasonal associates to help with the work load, and all of those costs were incurred during Q3 and advance of the significant spike in sales we experienced in November and December.
Net interest expense was $0.7 million for the quarter compared to $0.5 million last year. Our tax rate for the third quarter of fiscal 2010 was 32.3% compared to 35.2% last year with the lower tax rate principally due to hiring tax credits in certain jurisdictions.
In total for the third quarter fiscal 2010, we recorded income from continuing operations of $17.7 million or $0.23 per diluted share compared to income from continuing operations of $22.1 million or $0.27 per diluted share a year ago. This result was below our previously communicated guidance of $0.25 to $0.29. At a high level, the shortfall to the model was top line driven, partially offset by better than expected gross margin performance and a slight positive impact in both the tax rate and share count.
Our original guidance called for a Q3 SG&A rate to be flattish to last year, principally due to the investments in holiday preparation I indicated before. The expense deleverage not included in our original guidance was principally due to the shortfall in sales. Expenses flexed as expected on a lower sales base, but not to the extent of the planned SG&A rate.
Turning to the balance sheet, inventory ended the third quarter of fiscal 2010 at $1.006 billion compared to $918 million last year. Of the $88 million increase to last year, approximately $75 million was inventory to support higher store count and the intentional decision to move up delivery dates and bring import merchandise in early to avoid potential disruption that could have resulted from the container shortages coming out of Asia.
Inventory levels were up 6% per store when considering stores opened at the end of the quarter and stores opened in the month of November. We view this level of increase as timing related and would expect our inventory per store at the end of the fourth quarter to be flat to slightly up to last year.
Cash flow, which we define as cash provided by operating activities, less cash used in investing activities decreased by $89 million for the quarter compared to last year. This is largely attributable to the timing of inventory flow that I mentioned earlier and the higher CapEx related to new stores.
We ended the quarter with $51 million of cash and cash equivalents and $129 million of borrowings under our credit facility compared to $46 million of cash and cash equivalents and $1 million of borrowings under our credit facility last year. The increased level of borrowings is directly related to the share repurchase activity in fiscal 2010 and the increased inventory investment due to timing, as I mentioned earlier, partially offset by cash generated by operations over the past 12 months.
During Q3, we invested $108 million to opportunistically purchase 3.5 million shares at a weighted average price of $31.15 per share. Year-to-date, weve repurchased opportunistically $192 million of our stock or 6.0 million shares at a weighted average price of $32.16 per share. You may also recall that we executed $150 million accelerated share repurchase program or ASR in March of this year.
Although the final settlement of the total number of shares repurchased under our ASR will not be known until the contract ends. Had the ASR settled at the end of our fiscal third quarter, the total amount of shares repurchased under the ASR would have been 4.4 million shares. Combining our opportunistic activity within the same day ASR of 4.4 million shares, our total number of shares repurchased year-to-date would be 10.4 million or approximately 13% of our outstanding shares at the beginning of fiscal 2010.
We currently have $58 million remaining under our current authorization to repurchase shares opportunistically in the open market as of today.
For the third quarter, capital expenditures totaled $41 million compared to $23 million last year with the increase of $18 million primarily focused on new stores, refreshed stores and investments in energy management systems for our stores.
Depreciation expense for the quarter was $19.6 million, an increase of $1.4 million corresponding with the significant investments made in our business over the last 12 months.
Moving on to guidance, we are forecasting a total sales increase of 4% to 6% for the fourth quarter. This level of increase correlates to total sales between $1.52 billion to $1.55 billion, and is based on comparable store sales in a range of flat to up 2%, supplemented by some very successful new store performance which Chuck will touch on in a moment.
Additionally, we expect to benefit from one additional shopping day between Thanksgiving and Christmas.
Consistent with our prior guidance, we expect the fourth quarter gross margin rate will be below last year, due to higher domestic and import freight costs as well as lower IMU in certain deals, and holiday strategies designed to drive excitement infill traffic to our stores.
From an expense standpoint in Q4, we still anticipate leverage in most major expense areas, including store payroll, distribution and transportation, utilities and advertising. This favorability is assumed to be partially offset by higher debit card fees, resulting from rate hikes being passed on by network providers.
Based on these assumptions, Q4 EPS from continuing operations is now estimated to be in the range of $1.36 to $1.42 per diluted share compared to $1.31 per diluted share last year.
For the full year, we now expect income from continuing operations for fiscal 2010 to be in the range of $2.75 to $2.81 per diluted share, which I believe is consistent with the most recent first call consensus estimates.
This compares to our previous guidance of $2.82 to $2.90 per diluted share with the variance directly attributable with softer sales in third quarter which were assumed to continue through the fourth quarter. This range of EPS assumes an average annual diluted share count of approximately 79 million shares and does not contemplate any utilization of the $58 million remaining under our current share repurchase authorization. We now estimate our inventory turnover at 3.7 times, cash flow of approximately $200 million and net interest expense of approximately $2 million. For the full year fiscal 2010, we expect the comparable store sales increase in the range of 3.0% to 3.5%.
Now I will turn it over to Chuck for an update on real estate.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Cooper. During the third quarter, we opened 28 new stores and closed 13 stores leaving us with 1,389 stores and total selling square footage of 29.9 million at the end of the quarter. Subsequent to the end of Q3, we opened an additional 27
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Cooper. During the third quarter, we opened 28 new stores and closed 13 stores leaving us with 1,389 stores and total selling square footage of 29.9 million at the end of the quarter. Subsequent to the end of Q3, we opened an additional 27 new stores in November bringing our total number of new store openings for the year to 80 stores. Of the 80 store opening, 33 were new A type locations with the balance in more traditional centers. Year-to-date, weve closed 26 stores and anticipate closing six [ph] new more stores in Q4 bringing the total for the year to 42 closing in fiscal 2010.
Of the closings, 23 are actually relocations and are either older stores being relocated to higher traffic areas in better strip centers or stores previously too small for a full-size furniture department being relocated to a larger space to accommodate our full furniture assortment.
As Joe mentioned, weve been very encouraged by the performance of our new stores opened this year. For new stores with enough history to trend, we are forecasting annualized sales above our initial plans both in terms of dollars and productivity per foot.
Clearly, we are finding and securing better sites to open but a large portion of the success is attributed to a better store opening process beginning it to end; from merchandising to marketing to allocation of product through to store operations.
In terms of the A type locations, we continue to be pleased with performance to-date which has validated our decision to move aggressively in the better locations. Additionally, as we've said on a number of occasions, we believe we're attracting a meaningful amount of new customers to our A store format. Customers who have may not have shopped at Big Lots in the past or had a store in their normal shopping pattern.
Our traditional locations are also trending better than we anticipated. Even though these locations are not classified as an A type location, it's fair to say that a large majority of these stores are in better locations than we may have opened in the past. In particular, both A type and traditional stores opened in October and November have experienced a significant surge in business by combining grand opening activity along with the natural spike in holiday traffic we experienced in our stores during the fourth quarter.
Now, back to Steve for some closing remarks.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, hopefully, that gives you a very clear idea of our results, expectations for the fourth quarter, and an update on the real estate activity. Our total sales forecast for the Q4 of 4% to 6% would represent some very good performance on top of our record
componenttext:
So, hopefully, that gives you a very clear idea of our results, expectations for the fourth quarter, and an update on the real estate activity. Our total sales forecast for the Q4 of 4% to 6% would represent some very good performance on top of our record quarter a year ago. There are several encouraging trends, which could impact not only holiday but also highlight longer term opportunities for the company.
First and foremost, in merchandising early customer response to our nine weeks of Christmas strategies has been pretty solid, in particular the comp, strength and furniture, seasonal and home has continued on into Q4 as has the improvements in certain of our hardlines categories. Early selling in toys has been very competitive, which was not unexpected, but we have sufficient dry power to be aggressive.
The merchandising strategy is focused on key items in our how high is high testing are validating to us that we're on the right path. In terms of stores from my visits, I do believe our execution continues to improve. Our stores are becoming easier to shop. Our merchants have delivered more floor-ready merchandise in PDQs to help in presentation and were attracting a more talented team to Big Lots.
From a marketing perspective, were now approaching seven million rewards club members and our testing efforts are well underway to understand what generates the best and most productive response from our customers. I feel particularly good about our direction in real estate and the sales volume were experiencing in some of our new locations. It reinforces that new stores are likely the best investment we can be making right now for the future of the company. Store growth is at the top of the priority list for allocation of capital.
With that, Ill turn it back to T.J.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Steve. Katie, wed like to go ahead and open the lines for questions now.
componenttext: Thanks Steve. Katie, wed like to go ahead and open the lines for questions now.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Stein of Soleil Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jeff Stein of Soleil Securities.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for you on the toy business. Ive been looking at your circulars this year relative to last ten, in particular you are advertising some in-season toys where certainly over Black Friday you were undercut by Wal-Mart, and Im just trying to und
componenttext: Question for you on the toy business. Ive been looking at your circulars this year relative to last ten, in particular you are advertising some in-season toys where certainly over Black Friday you were undercut by Wal-Mart, and Im just trying to understand a little bit better what your strategy is on in-season toys, and if you are going to be in that business, dont you believe its important to be competitive on like items.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is yes. I think youre alluding to one or two items that Wal-Mart undercut us. We certainly should be undercut by competition and we dont go into the season, Jeff, planning to do that. We thought some of those name brand items and youre
componenttext:
The answer is yes. I think youre alluding to one or two items that Wal-Mart undercut us. We certainly should be undercut by competition and we dont go into the season, Jeff, planning to do that. We thought some of those name brand items and youre speaking specifically on the Paper Jamz and Zhu Zhu Pets, which, by the way, we are complete sellout on, that our intention is not to be undercut. We've always been a leader not only in toys and but in every product category that we're in. We take in and reacted to all the pricing that we felt that we needed to adjust. 
I think if you're in our stores today, you're going to find we're more aggressive than we potentially were over that weekend on a couple of those key items and on even more items. I think you'll find one of the interesting things about our marketing businesses is that we can work very close to the West and in fact we went through the Thanksgiving weekend and we were still able to react to the last week of December's piece the week before Christmas and make any kind of price adjustments that we needed to make. So along with the fact that you're going to see us extremely aggressive in print in the next four weeks, you're also going to see us extremely aggressive online. 
If you are awards member, we have done some really unique things. All along the way we planned on testing and finding out some of the things that really will excite our rewards members, but we can react on a day-to-day basis by putting items up online and changing prices. You're going to see that throughout the balance of the Christmas season.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Mann with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Mann with Johnson Rice.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you address a little bit what's going on in consumables in terms of what you think you need to do? Is it a function of getting some additional vendors, changing categories? How long do you think it will take to improve that business, especially since
componenttext: Can you address a little bit what's going on in consumables in terms of what you think you need to do? Is it a function of getting some additional vendors, changing categories? How long do you think it will take to improve that business, especially since it's such best churn?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I hope it starts to improve as soon as possible. I would tell you, David, and I kind of spoke to it on the last conference call and I would speak to it again today that although we're concerned always about businesses that are having what we conside
componenttext:
Well, I hope it starts to improve as soon as possible. I would tell you, David, and I kind of spoke to it on the last conference call and I would speak to it again today that although we're concerned always about businesses that are having what we consider to be challenges, the food part of our business is probably the thing that I'm most focused on, it's single most important business out of all of consumables and about 10% of our total business on a normal year. 
The good news is this in the fourth quarter consumables isn't near as a percent to total as it is in the first three quarters of the year and we're cranking on cylinders on the businesses that we need to be cranking on into the fourth quarter right now. But you are going to see a lot of newness and a lot of change in our food business coming into the first quarter. I really cant speak to it yet and dont want to, but there is going to be a lot of creativity, a lot of newness and a lot of excitement on the things that are selling at this particular point. If you go through the stores, a lot of the specialty foods that we really keyed into for Christmas right now, they are doing well. It's the day-in and day-out business. 
I think we're not the only one struggling. I may be wrong about this. Again, you guys know the business a lot better than I do, but the guys who have consumables, particularly the discounters is a very high percent total, and the last five or six quarters have struggled a lot more than we have on the top line of our business and they are consumables business and particularly food is much as double as what it is in our business. So, I dont know that we are the only one struggling. The consumer is feeling the pinch. Prices were up across the board. 
One of the things that I want to make sure of is this that our customer knows that even though prices are going up at major discounters and grocery stores that there is still that price value relationship and that distance between us and everybody else in that 10% to 50% savings range, and I think we are working very hard to understand that piece of it too. So, we are pretty consumed with all of consumables. There is still lot of great deals out there. There is still great deals in the stores. There is still going to be great deals going into January and into the first quarter that we are working on all the time and the consumer products companies are coming to us constantly on. So, Im encouraged what I think we are going to be capable of doing going into the first quarter.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Dan Wewer of Raymond James.
componenttext: The next question comes from Dan Wewer of Raymond James.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Steve, just to follow up on that. If you look at there were small box value retailers, let's say, Family Dollar, Dollar General. They've actually been calling out consumables as being their top performing category the last few years. I mean, there does
componenttext: So Steve, just to follow up on that. If you look at there were small box value retailers, let's say, Family Dollar, Dollar General. They've actually been calling out consumables as being their top performing category the last few years. I mean, there does seem to be demand for that business. Do you think there is a risk that a retail format that focuses on the close-outs and treasure hunts maybe it doesn't work for that day in, day out customer thinking about the mom and the band with two kids, and she has 10 or 15 minutes to shop. She knows another - there are certain brands that are always in the store?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there is two separate customers Dan, and I'll tell you what I think about that. Number one, from a location standpoint, I have said and I would say again that I believe although the Dollar Stores are doing a great job of executing. The Dolla
componenttext:
Well, I think there is two separate customers Dan, and I'll tell you what I think about that. Number one, from a location standpoint, I have said and I would say again that I believe although the Dollar Stores are doing a great job of executing. The Dollar Stores are kind of like the convenient store of choice today. Dan, I think probably the major big box retailers would say the same thing to you. Although, I think they are doing a great job, I think they are experiencing the fact that the challenged economic consumer has only x amount of money to spend and it's easier to go into a local Dollar Store and pick up that $8, $9, $10, $11, $12 worth of what I need today and can only afford today groceries versus how we execute a strategy or some of the other traditional retailers or grocery stores do. 
I don't think that it's not a strategy that's not important to us that we'll continue to. One of the things that's different between our customers and the customer that you alluded to is that our average customer spends as much as 35 minutes in our store. So they don't come to us for a quick pick up and a quick shop that could be challenging to us today. But in the long run, we'll still do a lot of consumables business and we'll still be a great place to come to for the best values you can possibly find.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you ever be open to the idea of perhaps reducing the space committed to consumables and reallocating that to the other discretionary categories where youve been achieving lot of success?
componenttext: Would you ever be open to the idea of perhaps reducing the space committed to consumables and reallocating that to the other discretionary categories where youve been achieving lot of success?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We constantly are challenging ourselves for our space allocation, but I would tell you I like our space allocation in consumables because were struggling right now in a particular category it doesnt mean that were going to throw in the towel and
componenttext:
We constantly are challenging ourselves for our space allocation, but I would tell you I like our space allocation in consumables because were struggling right now in a particular category it doesnt mean that were going to throw in the towel and the baby out with the water - bathwater. I think we run a great consumables business. I think we have been focused and executed slightly the way that we have in the past, in the way of showing great deals to our customer, and well get back on course. But I dont think were over spaced in consumables right now and I will tell you that there are other businesses that I think that weve challenged ourselves that we might be over spaced and we have already reduced some of the highly competitive plastic space in the last 12 months and reallocated it to pets, and are getting a great return on investment. 
Without speaking before we have a really good plan, I think youre going to see a shift in some of our businesses going into next fall. Into some of the businesses we continue to grow at a faster pace and are very successful in i.e. seasonal. We absolutely know that we need to expand our seasonal space in the third and the fourth quarter of next year. I think we do a pretty good job in the first and second quarter in lawn and garden and trim. Thats clearly going to have to come out of some businesses that are underperforming right now. But Id rather not speak to that until we have a really solid plan in place, maybe in another quarter or two.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Meredith Adler of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Meredith Adler of Barclays Capital.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question about free cash flow and stuff like that. It looks like in the latest quarter you took advantage of a low stock price and borrowed under the revolver to buy stock. You may not have a lot left under your volume, but would you continue to be opport
componenttext: Question about free cash flow and stuff like that. It looks like in the latest quarter you took advantage of a low stock price and borrowed under the revolver to buy stock. You may not have a lot left under your volume, but would you continue to be opportunistic? I'm going to guess that you get very cash rich by the time the holiday is over, you can pay down the revolver. But would you borrow more to buy back stock now?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We did have some borrowings under the revolver during the third quarter, but we anticipate under the current share repurchase program by the end of the year, we would be out of the revolver. Certainly, we are not afraid to leverage the business. Obviously
componenttext: We did have some borrowings under the revolver during the third quarter, but we anticipate under the current share repurchase program by the end of the year, we would be out of the revolver. Certainly, we are not afraid to leverage the business. Obviously, that's cheap right now. But that's the topic that each quarter we take up with the Board and partner with them on to what extent we execute future share repurchases. So, at this point I can't address it, but we do have $58 million left on the current share repurchase plan, and we'll address that with the Board.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You wouldn't necessarily be shy about asking for a bigger authorization or a new authorization?
componenttext: You wouldn't necessarily be shy about asking for a bigger authorization or a new authorization?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we've shown in the past, when it's appropriate, we will borrow to execute any capital investment or share repurchase when we feel that's the right thing to do. But at this point, I can't speak to that and thats something that we partner with o
componenttext: Well, as we've shown in the past, when it's appropriate, we will borrow to execute any capital investment or share repurchase when we feel that's the right thing to do. But at this point, I can't speak to that and thats something that we partner with our Board of Directors on.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question about Steves comments about the competitive environment in that you have a lot of flexibility and are becoming more promotional or improving your pricing between now and the holiday. I'm just wondering what you think that means for pr
componenttext: I have a question about Steves comments about the competitive environment in that you have a lot of flexibility and are becoming more promotional or improving your pricing between now and the holiday. I'm just wondering what you think that means for profitability? Does this vastly change your perspective on the profitability of the season or is this more tweaked sort of at the margin?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I was probably alluding to the toy business, Meredith, and I wanted to be very specific and I tried to make that clear in my comments. I guess I didnt, but I guess reiterating it to you. Weve a lot of dry powder. We do a pretty good jo
componenttext: Well, I think I was probably alluding to the toy business, Meredith, and I wanted to be very specific and I tried to make that clear in my comments. I guess I didnt, but I guess reiterating it to you. Weve a lot of dry powder. We do a pretty good job of going into the season with knowing or going we have to get aggressive somewhere for one reason or another. Markdowns are more than adequate in the budget at this particular point to take care of it. The only challenge to the fourth quarter from a margin standpoint that I think Joe alluded to in his comments is predominantly the freight part of the business, the inbound and the outbound freight, and then of course, the IMU. Weve taken a very aggressive stance in a couple of categories that we think it's the right thing to do to get through the quarter. We are still going to make a lot of money in the fourth quarter and feel pretty comfortable with the guidance that we gave.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just one question, when you were visiting with us in New York, you talked about some items that had been tested last year and I think they were sort of raise the ring kind of items. Is it too early to comment on about how those are doing? I think you
componenttext: Then just one question, when you were visiting with us in New York, you talked about some items that had been tested last year and I think they were sort of raise the ring kind of items. Is it too early to comment on about how those are doing? I think you rolled about to more stores?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will comment on a few of them and, by the way, we continue to do raise the ring and how high is high in this Christmas, too, just because we did at last Christmas. We made some major investments in a couple of categories that I would tell you pulling th
componenttext:
I will comment on a few of them and, by the way, we continue to do raise the ring and how high is high in this Christmas, too, just because we did at last Christmas. We made some major investments in a couple of categories that I would tell you pulling them merely is doing quite well and I will speak to maybe three areas. Number one is fireplace. We really went after the fireplace business. This is the third year in a row that we think we dominate the best value out there in that business and that is doing quite well. It is partially indicative of what happened in the third quarter in the furniture business although furniture across the space in all four of the businesses were good and that was very exciting. 
I will tell you that we had a good Thanksgiving weekend. We were really pleased with the Thanksgiving weekend and that had a lot to do with how high is high because we had an exceptional three days Thanksgiving weekend a year ago and to be able to comp on comp on those two, three big days of the year maybe the three biggest days of the year, although I'd have to go back and verify that, so don't hold me to that. We were really pleased. Fireplace, I just dropped my (inaudible). In home, particularly some of the better goods that we tested how high is high, blankets, microfiber, things like that in the $15 to $20 range, that did quite well. 
There was a third issue I wanted to talk to you about and I just went blank. Seasonal telemetry, particularly in the lighting business where we were testing how high is high and I think I alluded in the last quarterly call that how we were really encouraged about what we thought we could do in Christmas trees and we keep challenging ourselves on how high is high there. The fact that there is a lot of change in the lighting business if you're student of that business or a great customer, everybody needs new LED lighting this year and those investments have proven so far to this point to be really good investments in how high is high testing.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have Big Lots on my shopping list for Christmas lights this year.
componenttext: I have Big Lots on my shopping list for Christmas lights this year.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about the store growth as being the number one opportunity for capital and certainly, that's changing the philosophy over the last couple of years. Just how do you think about store growth relative to buyback? Then what do you think - wha
componenttext: You talked a lot about the store growth as being the number one opportunity for capital and certainly, that's changing the philosophy over the last couple of years. Just how do you think about store growth relative to buyback? Then what do you think - what numbers you would be thinking about for store growth for next year?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey Mitch, it's Chuck Haubiel, couple things on that. Number one, I think you've followed us long enough to realize that we will do whatever we think is in the best interest with respect to investing capital. Steve has been very clear about a desire to in
componenttext: Hey Mitch, it's Chuck Haubiel, couple things on that. Number one, I think you've followed us long enough to realize that we will do whatever we think is in the best interest with respect to investing capital. Steve has been very clear about a desire to increase or accelerate store growth once we have everything in place. One of the things that were trying to convey during this call is that as our team gets stronger and we have stronger leadership in the field, we are interested in doing everything we can to make sure that were growing at a rate that we are very comfortable with, not trying to hit a number, but in fact making sure that everyone of the stores that we open meet or exceed, if you will, what we believe they should be able to perform at that level of. We haven't given out numbers for next year yet. Well do that in March, during the first quarter call - fourth quarter call for next year, but it is something that we debate literally on a week-by-week or day-by-day basis.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mitch, this is T.J. I wouldnt think that those as mutually exclusive events. I mean, we just gave guidance of $200 million on cash flow opening 80 stores included in that number and other investments in the business. So, clearly there is enough cash be
componenttext: Mitch, this is T.J. I wouldnt think that those as mutually exclusive events. I mean, we just gave guidance of $200 million on cash flow opening 80 stores included in that number and other investments in the business. So, clearly there is enough cash being generated along with the back stop of the $500 million unsecured revolver to give us the flexibility to go either direction or both.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just thinking about the Class A stores, youve had enough history there now to think about - how theyve been performing kind of in the second year and what's kind of the parameters we should be thinking about for the progression of those as they
componenttext: Then just thinking about the Class A stores, youve had enough history there now to think about - how theyve been performing kind of in the second year and what's kind of the parameters we should be thinking about for the progression of those as they move into the second and third years of the maturity curve?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I apologize, because T.J. had unfortunately coughed that gives it in during your questions so we missed part of it. What kind of stores?
componenttext: Can I apologize, because T.J. had unfortunately coughed that gives it in during your questions so we missed part of it. What kind of stores?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I hope T.J. is okay. Could you talk a little bit just about thinking about the performance of those in the second and third years of the Class A stores?
componenttext: I hope T.J. is okay. Could you talk a little bit just about thinking about the performance of those in the second and third years of the Class A stores?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The A stores?
componenttext: The A stores?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, the A stores. Because from what we've seen, we've been very impressed with them. Thanks.
componenttext: Yeah, the A stores. Because from what we've seen, we've been very impressed with them. Thanks.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Joe, I'll start and Chuck can jump in. We've indicated that we've been certainly been pleased and encouraged by the performance of the A stores, as you mentioned eight opened in 2009, so we only have a few stores that have been open for a full yea
componenttext:
This is Joe, I'll start and Chuck can jump in. We've indicated that we've been certainly been pleased and encouraged by the performance of the A stores, as you mentioned eight opened in 2009, so we only have a few stores that have been open for a full year. As we've gone through 2010 and opened 30 or so, what we've learned is an A store - all A stores aren't going to be the same and some of them - it's an A store in the market where they reside. So, we can have an A store with company average volume, but it would be higher average volume than the surrounding market, and we can also have A stores that you've seen them. Our A stores here at the Polaris in Columbus where it performs significantly above company average. 
So, it's an A based on location. Does it have cotenants that can help draw traffic? Does it have population density? Those kind of attributes. So, we have been very pleased. But beyond the A stores we've been pleased with what we call the traditional stores that we've opened in 2010 and what Chuck's team and the finance team are working together to determine is really what are the key attributes that have been driving that success and how can we replicate it. We don't want to necessarily start ramping up new store growth and assume that all new stores are going to produce like they did in 2010. 
But if you - from a modeling standpoint when you see the spread between total sales and comp store sales, you can tell that there has been a little that the new stores and our comp stores are becoming more productive, and thats encouraging to us. But as Chuck said, we still want to be deliberate as we open new stores. We want to make sure we develop the talent in the field that can support the new store openings, and also that the economics in the new stores continue to be favorable for the profitability of the company.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Patrick McKeever with MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from Patrick McKeever with MKM Partners.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, Steve, if Im reading some of your comments about the Thanksgiving weekend and recent trends just in general and that the strong performance of some of the newer stores, some of Chuck's comments correctly. I mean, it does sound like there has been s
componenttext: So, Steve, if Im reading some of your comments about the Thanksgiving weekend and recent trends just in general and that the strong performance of some of the newer stores, some of Chuck's comments correctly. I mean, it does sound like there has been some inflection or pickup in the business since the end of the second quarter. So, I was just wondering if you could speak to that. Then the second question is just on the holiday, I mean in addition to lets say, it sounds like Zhu Zhu Pets are doing pretty well again this year. Im just wondering if you can talk about some of the other hot items may be as we get a little bit closer to Christmas either in Toys or elsewhere may be Electronics or Home any call outs there just on an item basis?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Patrick it's T.J. Specifically, on the Thanksgiving weekend I know there has been a lot written about those few days and certainly the month of November, the sales numbers were out yesterday and were probably pretty encouraging for most. I think
componenttext:
I guess, Patrick it's T.J. Specifically, on the Thanksgiving weekend I know there has been a lot written about those few days and certainly the month of November, the sales numbers were out yesterday and were probably pretty encouraging for most. I think what we're trying to communicate is when traffic really picked up and was at its peak rate in the month around Thanksgiving, clearly we had a great value proposition to pull people in and we did very well on that week on top of some pretty impressive numbers a year ago. So a lot of the items that were focused in the ad in the Thursday and Friday and Saturday specials did very well. A lot of those items were items that were tested in the prior year. 
So that's what we feel very good about going into the balance of holiday, and clearly, that's a little bit different trend than what we were communicating with late September and October. I think that's about as much as we can say on that at this point. So really to be able to look at fourth quarter and see a little bit of improvement compared to September and October and good response to categories or items that we need good response for where we've really made an investment and inventory was encouraging to us. But in terms of the holiday and hot items, I'll let Steve speak to it those best about.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mentioned fireplace. I mentioned some of the things happening in the home, like anything warmth [ph] related, seasonal trees lights, actually seasonal specialty food even though our food business has not been as strong, but that piece has been ver
componenttext:
Well, I mentioned fireplace. I mentioned some of the things happening in the home, like anything warmth [ph] related, seasonal trees lights, actually seasonal specialty food even though our food business has not been as strong, but that piece has been very, very good. Toys are all over the board. Its a really competitive Christmas. I think that's the best thing to say about that right now. We're going to see how the consumer decides to vote at the registers and there will be very interesting to see how a lot of people talk about their toy business. We're in the basic toy business. We're not in the electronic toy business. 
The business is shifting what a youngster wants today, if its got a plug on it, you can put it in your ear or something like that, thats what they like. Although I will say, in the electronics part of the business, the MP3 players continue to be really, really strong for us. The camera business continues to be - the digital camera business in particular and then the little Jazz video camera that we ran on Thanksgiving day, that we will come back again with one more time, between now and Christmas time was just off the wall. That was a good example of how high is high, too, the number - the quantity that we sold of that item. 
I think one of the things Im continuing to be more and more encouraged about is, is we really understand, and Ive always said that we just never understood how much we could really sell off any one thing. We continue to get better and better and closer to working to understand what the consumer really wants from us in quantities. The recliner Thanksgiving Day that weve been pretty traditional, weve done that for - this could have been our fifth year in a row, we sold probably more of those than almost as many as we had on hand to sell a year ago at this particular point. So were really getting better in understanding what our customer wants and buying into it. 
That comes at across from an inventory perspective, we stuck our necks out on inventory and I know that some of you didnt like the inventory levels, but our perspective is, is weve got, number one, be prepared for the customer and number two, have enough dry powder when these deals or half of our business become available to us. One of the reasons, Joe gave guidance for the end of the fourth quarter that we plan on being on about inventory or slightly up, this is that weve got dry powder in there for deals that we know were going to get or were waiting for the telephone calls to happen. We just dont know when theyre going to be there. Ive always said weve got to buy the deals that are right for the consumer and not play to the end of a quarter metric for one reason or another. So I think that's why he was being a little bit cautious and rightly so to you. So, I think that's a pretty good recap.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from John Zolidis of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from John Zolidis of Buckingham Research.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I know a couple of questions have already been asked about the store openings, and we have noted the improved sales metrics at the new stores. Have you given us an idea what the square footage growth is going to look like for 2011? The
componenttext: Two questions. One, I know a couple of questions have already been asked about the store openings, and we have noted the improved sales metrics at the new stores. Have you given us an idea what the square footage growth is going to look like for 2011? Then assuming that those new stores start comping at a rate that you would normally expect maturity curve, what's the ROIC going to look like at those stores relative to some of the stores you have opened in the past, assuming that, of course, that the expenses of operating those stores are higher?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, this is T.J., I'll start and then have Joe filling the blanks with me. But on the new store growth looking out, at the beginning of the year, we gave a three-year view that talked about square footage growth of 3% to 4% in each of the next three yea
componenttext:
John, this is T.J., I'll start and then have Joe filling the blanks with me. But on the new store growth looking out, at the beginning of the year, we gave a three-year view that talked about square footage growth of 3% to 4% in each of the next three years. We talked about 80 new stores this year, which we'll clearly deliver in a number more likely 90 stores or more in the next couple of years after that. That's about as much as we've given at this point. 
Obviously, we'll fill in the blanks come March. Along with that though you should expect that the closing number might go up a little bit also as we get more and more opportunities to relocate into some of these more productive locations. But, overall, that the net number of new stores opened next year and the year after ought to grow from where we are today. Looking at some of the more recent store openings, it is still fairly recent as we said, but I guess what we're encouraged by John is when we normally open a new store we're looking at that initial lease term of five to seven years, and saying are we delivering a good return or are we delivering return in closed store or better than our weighted average cost of capital which we estimate loosely to be around 12%. 
All we can really comment on at this point is based on sales, and it's early, year one sales were the most important - one of the most important numbers on that pro forma and we are ahead of pace. I think, thats about as much as we are comfortable saying right now. We're going to watch them through the holiday season, and we ought to be a lot more smarter the next time we speak.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then one more question. I just checked my notes from the third quarter conference call last year, and I believe you said at that time that November comps were plus 2% or something slightly better than that. Obviously, you ended the quarter plus 5%, so bus
componenttext: Then one more question. I just checked my notes from the third quarter conference call last year, and I believe you said at that time that November comps were plus 2% or something slightly better than that. Obviously, you ended the quarter plus 5%, so business really accelerated into December during the most important part of the season. With the order of 2% guidance that you are providing today what are you assuming, I guess, for the going forward period. Are you running a little bit ahead of that guidance? Are you assuming slowdown or are you assuming that business remains fairly consistent even though you are trying to up against a slightly more - a more difficult, I guess, December?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we are assuming is we did - as Steve and T.J. both mentioned. We had a good week four in November. We had a good Thanksgiving week but are flat to 2% guidance, what that represents is fairly consistent performance through week four of December, and t
componenttext:
What we are assuming is we did - as Steve and T.J. both mentioned. We had a good week four in November. We had a good Thanksgiving week but are flat to 2% guidance, what that represents is fairly consistent performance through week four of December, and then you have an extra shopping day. So, take out week four November and then kind of run through pretty consistent weeks one, two and three in November and then the first part of December. When we talked about - we've seen some improvement in November that's really off September and October. It's not necessarily - we're not projecting significant improvement off the third quarter trend, it's just that we saw a slowdown coming out of August. 
So, when you look at the 0.7 for the third quarter, that's a three month comp obviously; August, we outperform that and then September and October, we saw some softening which we've seen some improvement over those two months trends in November and we're encouraged by that. What we're looking at very, very closely right now is how are shoppers shopping after the Black Friday weekend and week one of December and week two of December are very, very important there to see how strong will they come back in the stores after that pretty successful weekend for across retail wouldn't just Big Lots. So, we believe our comp guidance is the best we know today. Then, of course, we roll into January where we had a very strong January of 2010 and we're comping on top of that. Now, our assortment going in there seems very compelling, we're very encouraged by it, but there is a lot of sales ahead of us hence our guidance.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, I guess, its a fair summary. August was good, slowdown to flattish September, October, a little bit of improvement in early November with the strong Black Friday weekend and basically assuming a little get back early December but the extra day gett
componenttext: So, I guess, its a fair summary. August was good, slowdown to flattish September, October, a little bit of improvement in early November with the strong Black Friday weekend and basically assuming a little get back early December but the extra day getting us in that 0% to 2% range.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a great summary. I'm glad that's on our transcript.
componenttext: That's a great summary. I'm glad that's on our transcript.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Laura Champine of Cowen and Company.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Want to understand the categories a little bit better, because as you mentioned Steve, the consumables have been the biggest issue and there are lesser part of Q4. Sounds like home and seasonal which are hugely important theyre doing well. So, Im ju
componenttext: Want to understand the categories a little bit better, because as you mentioned Steve, the consumables have been the biggest issue and there are lesser part of Q4. Sounds like home and seasonal which are hugely important theyre doing well. So, Im just trying to get a sense of what in your category performance, I mean, you mentioned the toys are challenging, but what in your category performance lead to the conservative guidance? Maybe if you can comment specifically on televisions and other larger ticket consumer electronics that will be helpful?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Were selectively in the close out business, when it comes to televisions and things like that. We dont play in it like the big boys play in it. I dont know that thats been a vibrant category for anybody right now, prices are extremely competit
componenttext:
Were selectively in the close out business, when it comes to televisions and things like that. We dont play in it like the big boys play in it. I dont know that thats been a vibrant category for anybody right now, prices are extremely competitive and theyll buy when there is a great deal, but we dont make a lot of money doing it. Actually I think there is piece in this weekend feast and pre-print that youll see that we think is pretty sharp, and youll probably see something else between now and the end of the holiday. But it's not a category that we run after unless its really offered to us. So, I would tell you thats a category that scares the heck out of me, were not specialist in it. 
Ive said in many occasions, if you stick a plug into the wall it's very low margin, no matter what it is and it always makes this shutter a little bit. Seasonal is doing well; we continue to see that driving our business in the fourth quarter. Home is doing well; we continue to see that driving our business in the fourth quarter. Toys, what I mentioned, was that it was competitive. Well see how challenging it is between now and the 25th of December. Again, we dont play in the electronics part of the toy business, we just play in the pure toy business, and we need to understand that. 
Thats been a challenge, not only this year but it has been for the last three or four years, and its probably somewhat of a down trending business to be quite honest with you. We need to understand how we want to position that toy business going forward. Well, consumables is consumables, I can beat it up the way you want to beat it up. I wish it was better for us than it's been. But it's a smaller piece as a percent of total of our business in the fourth quarter, and it's the lowest margin piece of our business. 
Overall, it a division in the company. I'll tell what's been slightly encouraging and I think I slightly mentioned it, the automotive business, our hard goods part of the business. When it comes to hardware, the toolset business has been terrific and we did a real strategic program for Christmas there on how high is high at price points and they're doing quite well. The electrical part of the business, the maintenance part of the business, the heater part of the business, particularly where it's been cool. If it doesn't snow like it did on the East Coast and they can get to the stores like yesterday. But that's part of the game. There's going to be weather, so we can't get too worried about that. You're not getting a weather report from us. Those have been good and encouraging. So I like all of those parts of the business.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you just let me hop in with one follow-on on consumables. As you look at your buyer group there, what's the background of your leadership in consumables buying? Is this being a product buying problem or is it a presentation problem in the stores?
componenttext: If you just let me hop in with one follow-on on consumables. As you look at your buyer group there, what's the background of your leadership in consumables buying? Is this being a product buying problem or is it a presentation problem in the stores?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our leadership has been very consistent since the day that I came in here. Our General Merchandise Manager has led the consumables business as Vice President, Divisional Merchandise Manager for the last five and a half years that I've been here and
componenttext:
Well, our leadership has been very consistent since the day that I came in here. Our General Merchandise Manager has led the consumables business as Vice President, Divisional Merchandise Manager for the last five and a half years that I've been here and longer than that. We have had some change in merchant decisions recently, and that's predominantly in the food and candy business. That's only in the last 60 days. So to be quite honest with you, it will take us a little while to find our way down the road there. But I would say product offering more than anything else. 
The fact that I think the consumer was challenged, I really do. I mean, everybody is playing off of us. I don't think we're the only ones whose consumable business is tough. I know that Dollar Stores are doing well. I think it's a convenience aspect, but that's my point of view, everybody else can say whatever they want to say. But the comps at the largest retailer in the world in the last six quarters have been down and 55% to 65% of their business is consumable. So, I must not be the only one who is suffering through this issue right now and trying to understand what the customer wants and what they want to spend.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Joe Feldman of Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: The next question comes from Joe Feldman of Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question for you, to follow-up on a earlier question about the comps and the guidance you gave. I was just curious, I guess, what's your degree of confidence that the zero to two is right? Because it is one of your toughest comparisons on a two-year sto
componenttext: A question for you, to follow-up on a earlier question about the comps and the guidance you gave. I was just curious, I guess, what's your degree of confidence that the zero to two is right? Because it is one of your toughest comparisons on a two-year stock basis even and I'm just worried what it is made sense to give like a slightly negative to slightly positive range as opposed to a zero to two. I'm curious as to what drove that decision maybe.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We consider what should our range be and the fourth quarter it can be tough because you're facing the Christmas. December is ahead of you and then kind of a new season January that we're going up against the strong January. All I can tell you is we do a l
componenttext:
We consider what should our range be and the fourth quarter it can be tough because you're facing the Christmas. December is ahead of you and then kind of a new season January that we're going up against the strong January. All I can tell you is we do a lot of work on forecasting sales every which way you possibly can do, looking at our trends by category, across the country and we believe that based on what we know today in our trends zero to two is the right number. Would it be easier to with our share price today to do a negative something up to a low positive, it may be but that's not how we forecast our sales. 
We forecasted and guide the Street to the best number that we believe that we'll attain. The consumables area that has been challenged is a lower percentage of our business in the fourth quarter. Some of the categories that have been winning seasonal is a higher percentage. Certainly the jury is still out on toys. We'll see how that goes. But all the category information and performance that we've talked about and the calendarization through the quarter November, December and January, we believe that that guidance is prudent, but we'll talk in three months and see how it goes.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then one other follow-up. Just on the store mix, going forward as you guys open more stores and I apologize if you already said it, but with the A locations and even those locations that may be not be quite A but you've considered them better locations, h
componenttext: Then one other follow-up. Just on the store mix, going forward as you guys open more stores and I apologize if you already said it, but with the A locations and even those locations that may be not be quite A but you've considered them better locations, how should we think of that mix going forward as you open the new stores next year and beyond? Like will that continue to skew upwards or is it still going to be a pretty small percentage like it was this year or -

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't know yet, quite frankly. I mean the reality of it is based on the openings this year and I guess to reiterate what we said earlier, we're very encouraged and even some of the more traditional locations, if you will, are probably in better locatio
componenttext: We don't know yet, quite frankly. I mean the reality of it is based on the openings this year and I guess to reiterate what we said earlier, we're very encouraged and even some of the more traditional locations, if you will, are probably in better locations that we've opened in the past. I think that you should expect that we'll have a very continued focus on those types of folks.

componenttext: We have. But when we give guidance where the quarter do-date comp is outside the range, we communicate that and tell you why. The first quarter of this year is an example, were running higher than our guidance but we believed - we understood the trends in the business, and what happened was March and April were a lower comp than February, for a number of reasons we enumerated in the first quarter. But in this case we are running inside that range.

componenttext: Looking ahead over the next 60 days or so, even when you look back at the third quarter of last year your furniture business was down in those single digits and then in the fourth quarter it was up high singles. If I look in seasonal, third quarter last year you were down one and then you finished up in the fourth quarter up mid single, so your compares step in significantly, you still expect to perform in that 0% to 2% range that youre doing month-to-date, even though those compares get a lot harder in some of those categories? headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I mentioned, you calendarize the weeks through December, you do get the extra shopping day, history has told us and we believe that that's a contributor to the comp. So, we're running - it won't be specific, but a pretty steady assumed performance thro
componenttext: As I mentioned, you calendarize the weeks through December, you do get the extra shopping day, history has told us and we believe that that's a contributor to the comp. So, we're running - it won't be specific, but a pretty steady assumed performance through the first three weeks, you get a lift and week four of December, and then you run through the balance of the quarter, and that's the forecast that we have, and that's the forecast we're communicating.

componenttext: Just to walk down the P&L. On SG&A, Joe you talked about SG&A leverage in the fourth quarter, can you just get a little bit more granular, what's your expected breakeven point?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chuck, we haven't given the breakeven point by quarter. We have said for the year, it's roughly a flat comp to leverage SG&A. Clearly, there are a lot of different levers in the fourth quarter versus third quarter. The third quarter is our most difficult
componenttext: Chuck, we haven't given the breakeven point by quarter. We have said for the year, it's roughly a flat comp to leverage SG&A. Clearly, there are a lot of different levers in the fourth quarter versus third quarter. The third quarter is our most difficult quarter to do the leverage, no doubt because we're paying forward, so to speak, it incurring a lot of costs in the third quarter that aren't there in the fourth, as we've now opened those new stores and finished our refresh stores and all the other things that we've talked about. So, we very much view the third quarter as the yield quarter and leverage should return in the fourth quarter.

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Last question. Just on the consumables category. It sounds like Steve, you really looked at it, and then certainly it sounds like you're trying to fix it. But, I'm just trying to get a sense for - to follow-up on the earlier question. How much do you thin
componenttext: Last question. Just on the consumables category. It sounds like Steve, you really looked at it, and then certainly it sounds like you're trying to fix it. But, I'm just trying to get a sense for - to follow-up on the earlier question. How much do you think it could be structural? I mean, if you look at the strength that Family Dollar and Dollar General are having, and I know you guys had a lot of store overlap with them in the southeast and then you've added a lot more SKUs to getting special pack sizes that are adding hours, I mean they're just not the same companies there were five years ago. So, I guess, how much do you think it's structural versus company specific?

headline: Big Lots Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: We blame ourselves. I really cant blame whats going on and around us. I mean I think it's internal and we have to have a better offering for our customer and we will do a much better job. Remember, the crossover of that customer from our customer is
componenttext: We blame ourselves. I really cant blame whats going on and around us. I mean I think it's internal and we have to have a better offering for our customer and we will do a much better job. Remember, the crossover of that customer from our customer is really at a smaller level than it is from the big boys. I mean our traditional crossover customer comes from the big box retailers, and thats predominantly where our customer shops from. I mean I take the blame for consumables. I dont know that anybody else is doing it to us.

componenttext: We have not changed our tax rate guidance for the year, Joan. I believe we were 38 to 38.5% for the year, which does suggest that our tax rate will be higher in fourth quarter, but historically is, third quarter is historically the lowest quarter of the year. In terms of your first question on depreciation, our guidance for the year is approximately $80 million. So we would need to see a little bit of a bump in the fourth quarter to come up to that number. As we've talked about, we had a lot of store opening activity this fourth quarter. So there are more assets coming on. Katie, we would like to go ahead and thank everybody for their interest and participation today. We'll speak to you all again in a month. Thank you.
